The Seventh Year of George II.

CHAP. I.

AN Act for granting and continuing to his Majesty an additional Duty on Beer, Ale, Strong Waters, Wine, Tobacco, and other Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned. Page 1

An Act for granting to his Majesty a further additional Duty on Wine, Silk, Hops, China, Earthen, Japanned, or Lacquered Ware, and Vinegar; and also a Tax of Four Shillings in the Pound on all Salaries, Profits of Employments, Fees, and Pensions, to be applied to pay an Interest of Five Pounds per Cent, per Annum for the Sum of Three Hundred Thousand Pounds, or such Part thereof as shall remain unpaid on the Twenty fifth Day of December One thousand seven hundred and thirty three, and towards the Discharge of the said Principal Sum. Page 5

CHAP; III.

CHAP. IV.

An.AS for allowing further Time to Persons in Offices or Employ-ployments to qualify themselves pursuant to an ASy intituled, An Act to prevent-the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons, veil affected to his Majesty's government and the church of Ireland as by law established, have- through ignorance neglected, or have been prevented by sickness or other accidental causes, to take and subscribe the oaths, and to make and subscribe the declaration, and to receive the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne,

: Anne 6. intituled, Atn act to prevent the further growth of popery, and thereby many have incurred several incapacities, disabilities, penalties, and forfeitures: for remedy whcro£ be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons, who now arc or have been in the actual possession of any office or offices civil or military, or that receive, or have received any pay, salary, fee, or wages belonging to, or by reason of any office or place of trust, by reason of any patent or grant from his Majesty, or that have, or have had, any command or place of trust from or under his Majesty or any of his prcdcceflors, or by his or their authority* or by authority derived from him or them within this realm, that were required by the said above mentioned act to take and subscribe the oaths, and to make and subscribe the'declaration, and to receive the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper according to the directions of the said act, who have incurred any incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, or penalties by omitting or neglecting to take and subscribe the said oaths, and to make and subscribe the said declaration, and to receive the said sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indcmniiied, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties incurred by reason of £uch omission or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them or any of them, or by authority derived from them or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by reason of fuclt neglect or omission: but that all fufti acts shall be and are hereby declared to be as good and clfeftua), as if all and every, such person and persons had taken ami subscribed the said oaths, and received the said ftcrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration in manner as aforesaid; any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding: nevertheless so as such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make and subscribe the said declaration, in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as aredirested and appointed by the said act, to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the first day of August, which shall be in the year of ourXord one thousand seven hundred and thirty four.

II. Provided, That this act, or any thing therein contained, shall not extend to reftovc or intitle any person or persons to any office or employment already actually Avoided by judgment of any of his Majesty's courts of record, or filled up by any other person: but that such office or employment shall be and remain in the person or persons, who is or are now intiried by law to the fame, as if this act had never been made.

CHAP. VI.

An Act to prevent Persons converted from the Popish to the Protestant Religion, and married to Popish Wives, or educating their Children in tbs Popish Religion,from ailing as fujlices of the Peace.

No convert H £ R E A S it is necessary for the preservation of the

shall be juf- f y protestant Interest, and of the peace of this kingdom, that whole wife a no persons whatsoever should be justices of the peace in any part drcnundcrle thereof, but such only as are of known affection to the protestant educated pa- religion and our present happy establishment: be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That no person, who is or shall be converted from the popish to the protestant religion, shall be capable of being or acting as a justice of the peace within this kingdom, whose wife is or shall be a papist, or who doth educate or cause to be educated in the popish religion all or any of his children, who shall he

under The seventh Year a/* George II.

under the age of sixteen years; and if any person, who is or shall be converted from the popish to the protestant religion, shall from and after the twenty ninth day of-September, which shall be.in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty four, act as a justice of the peace within this kingdom, whose wife is' or shall be a papist, or -who doth educate, or cause to be educated, in the popish religion all or any of his children, who shall be under the age of sixteen years, such person, so acting contrary to the true intent and meaning of this act, shall upon legal conviction thereof suffer one year’s imprisonment, without bail or mainprize, and forfeit the sum of one hundred pounds, to be recovered by bill, plaint, or information, in any of his Majesty courts of record; one moiety of which forfeiture is to be to the use of his Majesty, his heirs and successors, and the other moiety to him or them, who shall sue for the same 5 and from thenceforward, such person so convicted as aforesaid, shall be for ever incapable of being an executor, administrator, or guardian.

WHEREAS the seas about this kingdom have heretofore been plentifully stored with fish, which of late years have been greatly diminished by methods of fiflting, which destroy the spawn and fry of fish: and whereas it will highly conduce to the publick weal of this kingdom to encourage the fisheries thereof: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the ad-

vice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty ninth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty four no drag-net or other sea-net, which hath a mash of less than three inches and a half from knot to knot, shall be made use of in catching any kind of fish (except herrings, pilchards, sprats, shrimps, and prawns) upon any part of the coait of this kingdom, or within any of the bays, harbours, rivers, or creeks thereof*, nor Avail any false or double bottom codd or pouch, or any other net, though of legal size, be placed upon or behind the other in order to take and destroy small fish; and if any person or persons shall from and after the said twenty ninth day of September one thousand seven hundred and thirty four make use of any drag-net or other sea-nct, which has a mash of less than three inches and an half from knot to knot, in catching any kind of iifh (except herrings, pilchards, {prats, flmmps, and prawns) on any part of the sea-coasts of this kingdom, or within any of jthe bays, harbours, rivers, or creeks thereof, or shall place any false or double bottom, codd, or pouch, or any other net, though of legal size, upon or behind any other in order to take and destroy small fish, such person or persons so offending, and being thereof convicted upon Ins or their appearance, or default after summons before one or more justice or justices of the peace of the county or place where such persons so offending hath or have their ufuaf place of abode, by tl\e oath of one or more credible witness or witocfles (which oath such justice and justices of the peace is and are hereby impowered to administer, or by confession .1 of

An Act for the laying and felling of all forts of Corn and Mealy and other things in the said Act mentioned by 'weight; and for the more effectual preventing the Frauds committed in the buying and selling thereof; and for regulating the Price and AJftzc of Bread; and for better regulating the Markets.

WHEREAS it hath been found impracticable to prevent frauds and ijoiiltj!

abuses in felling of com by measure, ami that it is moil equal between buyer and feller to sell the same by weight; be it therefore emitted by the King's

1110ft excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty ninth day of September, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty four, all wheat, rye, meaflin, pease, beans, barley, bear, oats, Ihillin, cutlins, meal, flour, and malt, shall be fold and delivered by weight, and not by measure, or in any other manner whatsoever.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That such weight shall be according to the avrir-du-psis pound, fourteen pounds whereof shall make a stone, and eight hone one hundred weight, and twcuty hundreds one tun, to be handing weight, with an even and equal beam or ballance; and all bargatus, contracts, and agreements, made after the said twenty ninth day of September for felling such wheat, rye, meaflin, pease, beans, barley, bear, oats, ihillin, cutlins meal, flour, and malt, by any other different weight, or for felling the fame by measure, or for felling thereof in any other manner than by weight, or for giving, adding, or allowing, any quantity of such wheat, rye, meaflin, pease, beans, bar* ley, bear, oats, ihillin, meal, flour, cutlins, or malt, to the quantity agreed to be sold, or for giving, or making any addition, or allowance to the stone, hundred, tun, or other weight, shall be, and are hereby declared to be, void to all intents ami purposes whatsoever.

III. An Act for making more effectial an Act passed in the Fifth Year of the Reign of his present Majesty King George the Second, intituled, An Act for repairing the Road leading from the City of Dublin to the Town of Dtmleer in the County of Lowth.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the fifth year of his present Majesty King 3 gT/c.%.

" George the second, intituled, An Act for repairing the road leading from 5 a.i. is-the city of Dublin to the town of Dunleer in the county of Louth, several tolls and duties were granted and made payable for repairing the said road; which said act was to commence from the tenth day of March in the year of our Lord one thousand feren hundred and thirty one, and from thence to continue in force for and during the term of twenty one years: and whereas the trustees appointed to put the said act in execution have borrowed the sum of eleven thousand pounds on the credit thereof, which is still unpaid, and have applied the fame, together with the tolls collected by virtue of the said act, in amending the said road, and great pro* gress hath been made in repairing thereof, yet the fame cannot be effectually amended and kept in good repair, nor the said sum of eleven thousand pounds, or any other sum that shall be hereafter borrowed for the use of the said road, repaid, unless some other provision be made for that purpose; be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said act made in the fifth year of his present Majesty King George the second, and all and every the powers, authorities, articles, rules, penalties, and clauses therein contained, except what are hereby altered, shall be of full force and effect, and shall continue, and be executed from and after the expiration of the said term of twenty one years for and during the further term of twenty two years, and from thence to the end of the next session of Parliament for the intents and purposes in the said act and herein after mentioned, as if the fame powers and authorities granted and given by the said act were herein again repeated and re-, enacted in the body of this present act; any thing in the said former act contained to the contrary hereof notwithstanding.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, from time to time during the continuance of the said former or this present act to make out warrants or orders in writing under their hands directed to the treasurer or receiver of the said tolls, thereby requiring him to pay thereout to the person or persons named in such warrant or order, their executors, administrators, and assigns, the growing interest of the sum of money mentioned in such warrant or order, as the same shall from time to time become due, until such time as the principal sum mentioned in such warrant or order shall be paid off and discharged at one entire payment.

CHAP. XX.

An Act for making more effectual an Act passed in the fifth Year of the Reign of his present Majesty King George the Second, intituled, An Act for repairing the Road leading from the City of Cork to the Brook which bounds the Comities of Cork and Tipperary, near the Foot of Kilworth Mountain, and for other Pur-ptfes herein mentioned.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the fifth year of the reign y v of his present Majesty King George the second, intituled, An act for repairing the road leading from the city of Cork to the brook, which bounds the counties of Cork and Tipperary, near the foot of Kilworth mountain, several tolls and duties were granted and made payable for repairing the said road, which said act was to commence from the twenty fifth day of March in the year of our.Lord one thousand fev.en hundred and thirty:two, and from thence to continue in force for and during the term of twenty one money bor-years; and whereas the trustees appointed to put the said act in execution have borrowed certain films of money on the credit thereof, which are.dill unpaid, and have applied the fame, together with the tolls collected by virtue of the said act, in amending the said roads, and some.progress hath been made in repairing thereof, yet the fame cannot be effectually amended and so kept, nor the said funi of money so borrowed, or airy other sum that shall be hereafter borrowed, for the use of the said road and the other purposes herein after mentioned, repaid without some other provision be made for that purpose: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the;lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That ithe said act made in the fifth year of the reign of his present Majesty King George the second, and all and every the powers,

CHAP. XXII.

WHEREAS be an act passed in the third year of the reign of his present most sacred Majesty King George the second, intituled, An act for repairing the road leading from the city of Dublin to the town of Navan, in the county of Meath, several tolls and duties were granted and made payable for repairing tire said road; and also that the Iaft mentioned or additional roads may be effectually repaired; may it please your most excellent Majesty that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and com-. 3 mons

XXII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the toll or duty hereby granted shall take place and have continuance from and after the tenth day of June next for and during the term of forty one years.

XXIII. Provided nevertheless, That if at any time before the expiration of the said term of forty one years all parts of the said roads shall be sufficiently amended and repaired, and so adjudged by the majority of the trustees, appointed or hereafter to be chosen by virtue of this act, by an adjudication made, and re-payment of such money as shall have been advanced or borrowed, with interest for the fame, and the costs and charges thereof, the said tolls and duties shall cease and determine; any tiling herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

XXIV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the continuing of a sufficient number of able persons to he trustees for putting in execution all and every the powers in this act contained for and during the continuance thereof, it shall and may he lawful to and for the said trustees, or any five or more of them, upon the death of any of the said trustees, or their removal, or refuting to ad in the said trull, from time to time, and at all times hereafter during the term aforesaid, to elect, nominate, and appoint in the room of such trustee or trustees so deceased, removed, or refuting to ad, so many more fit and able person or persons living in the said counties of Down and Antrim, to be joined with the said trustees in the execution of all and every the power and powers in them reposed by virtue of this act; and all and every person or persons so to be chosen trustee or trustees to join in putting this act in execution, as they are herein before qualified to do, shall, and may, and are hereby impowered to act to all intents and purposes in as full, large,

XXVI. through the fame, are become so ruinous and bad, that in winter-season many parts thereof is impartible for waggons, carts, carrs, and carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in good repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highways and roads may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and furticient repair, so that all persons may travel through the fame with fafetys be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better surveying, ordering, amending, and keeping in repair, the said highway or road, the right honourable Alexander carl of Antrim, sj G. s. 16. the right honourable Hugh earl of Mount Alexander, the right honourable Clotworthy lord viscount Mafarecn, the right honourable James lord viscount Charlc-mont, the right honourable Trevor lord viscount Hillsborough, the right honours, able James Lord viscount Limerick, the right honourable Brabazon lord viscount Duncannon, the right reverend Francis lord bishop of Down, the right reverend Henry, lord bishop of Dromore, the honourable Mr. justice Ward, the honourable 3 John

XI. And forafnuich as the monies, so to be collected by such' receipt of the said toll, will not at present be sufficient for the speedy repairing of the said highways or roads: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, shall, and may, and are hereby impowered from time to time by writing under their respective hands and seals to allign over the said separate toll or duty hereby granted, or any part thereof, the coils and charges whereof to be borne and paid out of such separate toll or duty, for any term or time during the continuance of this act, as a security for any sum or sums of money by them to be borrowed for that purpose, to such person or persons, or their trustees, who shall advance and lend the fame, to secure the repayment thereof with lawful interest, or left, if the fame can be so had j which said money borrowed shall be applied and disposed of, as the toll or duty is by this act to be applied and disposed of, and to no other use Or purpose whatso'ever.

XII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, from- time to time during the continuance of this present act, to make out warrants or orders in writing, under their hands directed to the treasurer or receiver of the said tolls, thereby requiring him to pay thereout to the person or persons named in such warrant or order, their executors, administrators, and assigns, the growing interest of the sum of money mentioned in such warrant or order, as the same shall from time to time become due, until such time as- the principal sum mentioned-in such warrant or order shall be paid off and discharged; provided that no warrant or order, to be issued to the said treasurer or receiver by virtue of this act, shall be for any greater sum than fifty pounds.

An Act for repairing the Road leading from Tu Bounds of the Counties of Clare and Galway to the 5 in the said County of Clare, and from thence to the ties of the City of Limerick.

An Act for granting and continuing to his Majesty an additional Duty on Beer, Ale, Strong Waters, Wine, Tobacco, and other Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons required by this a St to make up, return, or give in, any such lift or any ways concerned therein, shall wilfully omit out of any such lift any person or persons, who ought to be inserted, or shall wilfully insert any person or persons who ought to be omitted, or shall take any money or other reward for omitting or inferring any person whatsoever, he or they so offending shall for every person, so omitted or inserted in such lift contrary to the meaning of this act, forfeit such sum and sums of money, not less than the sum of five pounds, nor exceeding the sum of twenty pounds, as the justices at the general quarter-sessions of the peace shall think fit to determine according to the nature of the offence; who are hereby impowered and required, on examination and proof of such offence, in a summary way to set the said fine, as is before limited and appointed; wluch fine, so set and imposed, the said justices and clerk of the peace are hereby required to estreat into his Majesty's court of Exchequer.

CHAP. IV.

An Act for the further ’Encouragement and Improvement of the Flaxen and Hempen Manufactures,

R,fiMU) WHEREAS great frauds are daily committed in the packing of hemp;

c.i.6. y y £or remC()y thereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the fird day of May one thousand seven hundred and thirty Gx, it shall and may be lawful for the trustees appointed for encouraging the hempen and flaxen manufactures of this kingdom, or any five of more of them, to licence and appoint such and so many fit and proper persons in such places of this kingdom, as they shall judge most convenient, to view, examine, and weigh all such dred hemp, as shall be produced and offered for that purpose, and if such hemp appear to be good and merchantable, such person so licensed shall and may pack and make up the fame, and mark on each package the weight of the hemp therein contained,

and seal or damp the fame with the name of such packer, and die county in which he resides, or such other impression as the said trustees shall think fit to appoint; for all which such packer shall and may demand and take any sum to be appointed by the said trustees, not exceeding six pence for every hundred weight of hemp so packed and marked: and if any person or persons being licensed as aforesaid Gulf seal or damp any package of hemp, that is not merchantable, or shall mark the fame with a greater weight than such package contains, such person or persons so offending, shall forfeit to the person or persons that shall be damnified by buying such hemp, the sum of six shillings for every hundred weight of such package so damped or marked as aforesaid, on conviction before a justice of the peace or chief magistrate within their respective jurisdictions on the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses, which oath such justices of the peace and chief magistratci are hereby impowered to administer; and they arc also hereby impowered to hear and finally to determine such offences; such penalties to be levied by warrant of such judice of the peace or chief magistrate, together with twelve pence for the eondable who shall execute the fame, by didrefs and falc of the offenders goods; and all such packers shall be subject to such rules, orders, and directions, as the said trustees, or any five or more of them, shall think fit, provided the fame be not contrary to this act; and the said trustees, or any five or more of them, shall be impowered to administer to every such packer as aforesaid such oath, as they shall think proper for the faithful execution of the said office.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons from and after the fird day of AuguA one thousand seven hundred and thirty six shall sell or expose to sale, one hundred weight, or any greater quantity of drelfed hemp of the growth of this kingdom, not being packed and marked as aforesaid, all such hemp shall be forfeited to the person or persons, who shall seize the fame; and it shall and may be lawful to and for any person or persons to seize and carry the fame before any judice of the peace or chief magistrate within their respective jurisdictions, who are hereby impowered upon the confession of the parties, or the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses (which oath they are hereby authorized to administer) to hear and finally determine the fame, and to condemn or discharge such hemp so seized as aforesaid; and that if any person shall counterfeit any such seal or damp, every such person, being thereof lawfully convicted, shall incur and be subject to the fame pains, penalties, and punishments, as in and by an act made in the sixth year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the fird, intituled, An act for the better regulating the buying and selling of 'I- yarn and doth, and further improving the hempen and flaxen manufactures of thil ting-

VI. And whereas it has frequently happened, that purchasers for valuable confiaerations under deeds of lease and release have been prevented from recovering their rights, for want of being able to produce the lease for a year, which is often lost or mislaid: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all cases the recital of a lease for a year in the deed of release shall be deemed and taken to be full and sufficient evidence of, such lease.

CHAP. VII.

An Act for encouraging the Planting of Timber Trees.

WHEREAS persons seized of estates for life, with remainders over, have often improved their estates by planting of timber trees: and whereas the benefit of such improvements by the laws now in being defeends intirely to the person next in reversion or remainder, without- any consideration had for such improvement, to the frequent impoverishment of younger children and ruin of creditors: and whereas tenants in tail, who have in their life time made such improvements, often dye without docking the intail; by which means the said improvements defeend In the same manner as the improvements made by tenants for life: and whereas many are hereby greatly discouraged from planting timber-trees, to the manifest prejudice of the kingdom: to remedy therefore the said mischiefs, and to encourage tenants if tenant far life and in tail to plant timber-trees; be it enacted by the tail 'remain- ^Hs’s m0^ excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and con-der over, sent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this pre-IScmcu-’ lent Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, ndTratora Tn- Tl'at any person seized of an estate for life, or in tail, with a titled to a remainder or remainders over, shall in his life-time plant on his said

CHAP. VIII.

An Act to prevent the Evil arising by the Retailers of Beer, Ale, Brandy, Rum, Geneva, Aquavita, and other Spirituous Liquors, giving Credit to Servants, Day-Labourers, and other Persons, who usually work or ply for Hire or Wages.

WHEREAS many great inconveniences have arisen, ami do daily arise, from the credit usually given by retailers of strong beer, ale, brandy, rum, geneva, aquavitae, and other spirituous liquors, to servants, day-labourers, and other persons, who usually work or ply for hire or wages; by means of which credit servants, day-labourers, and other persons, who usually work or ply for hire or wages, are induced and tempted to resort too frequently to the houses or shops of the retailers of such liquors, where they often drink to excess, and thereby frequently run into debt, and lay themselves under the temptation of pur-loyning their mailers goods to discharge such debts, and do further by that means destroy their health, and render themselves incapable of discharging the business of their respective callings and stations, and are often thrown into goal, where they lye in a miserable and starving condition, to the ruin of themselves and their families; which mischiefs might be in a great measure, if

201

not wholly prevented, if some restraint was put upon the credit usually given to the persons aforesaid for such liquors by the retailers of the fame: for remedy thereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That no retailer of strong beer, ale, brandy, rum, geneva, aquavits, or other spirituous liquors, who shall from and after the first day of May, which will be in the year of our Lord one thousand feren hundred and thirty against any of the persons aforesaid, their executors or administrators j and all promissary notes, bonds, or other writings obligatory, given as a security for the payment of such debts so contrafted, are hereby declared void and of no effect: and in case any such servant or day-labourer, or other person or persons, who usually work or ply for hire or wages shall leave any pawn or XX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said trustees, or any five or more of them, may and are hereby impowered from time :to time, as they shall see convenient or think fit, to compound or agree by the year or otherwise, with any person or persons using to travel through the turnpike or turnpikes to be erected, with any milch cows, horse, mare, or gelding, afs or mule, or with any coach, berlin, chariot, calash, chaise, chair, waggon, cart, car, or other carriage, for any sum or films of money to be paid quarterly from time to time after such agreement shall be made.

XXI. Provided also, and it is hereby declared, That no person shall be charged with any of the tolls or duties aforesaid, who shall pass through any of the turnpikes to be erected by this act, who shall carry any quantity of Kilkenny coals, or of stones, gravel, or other materials for repairing of the said road, or any of the roads in the parish in which the fame do lye, or in any of the neighbouring parishes; nor shall any person or persons be chargeable with the said toll or duty, for any carts, cars, or waggons loaded with corn in the straw only; nor for any ploughs, harrows, or other implements of husbandry in order to the using or repairing of the fame in the several parishes, in which the said highway or road hereby intended to be repaired do lye; nor shall any toll or duty be demanded or taken at any of the turnpike or turnpikes to be erected, for any horse, mare, gelding, afs, or mule, or other cattle going to water, or for any post-horse carrying the mail or packet, or for such horse as is or shall be used only to ride on by the owner or driver of any waggon, cart, or carriage; provided such horse pass through the said turnpike or turnpikes with such waggon, cart, or carriage: nor shall any toll or duty be demanded or taken for the horses of soldiers passing that are upon their march, or for waggons, carts, cars, or other carriages attending them, or for horses, waggons, carts, cars, or other carriages travelling with vagrants sent by passes, or with prisoners transmitted from one part of the kingdom to another.

CHAP. XV.

An Act for repairing the Road leading from the Town of Antrim in the County of Antrim through the Towns of Ballymenagh and Ballymoney in the said County, and to the Town of Coleraine in the County of Londonderry.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading from the town of Antrim in the county of Antrim, through the town of Ballymenagh and Ballymoney in the said county, and to the town of Coleraine in the county of Londonderry, by reason of several hollow ways, and of the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in winter season many parts thereof are impassable for waggons, carts, cars, and carriages, and very dangerous for The road travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the paircd'bj the ^aws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in oidinary good and sufficient repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highway and road may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords Spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That Trulttcs for the better surveying, ordering, amending, and keeping in thereof!* repair the said highway or road, the right honourabls may%*Vc' Alexander carl of Antrim, the right honourable Arthur earl m if wi-erpo- of Donegal), the right honourable Clotworthy lord viscount vmjt’hmc Maffareen, the right honourable Trevor lord viscount Hills-TnnfmMd borough, the right honourable Marcus lord viscount Tyrone,

CHAP. XVI.

An Act for accepting the solemn Affirmation or Declaration of the People called Quakers, instead of an Oath in the usual Form.

WHEREAS by an act passed in the first year of the reign of his present most excellent Majesty King George the second, intituled, An act for accepting the solemn affirmation or declaration of the people called £hiahers} instead of an oath in the usualform, it is cnatted, That from and after the twenty fifth day of " March, which was in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and " twenty eight, every Quaker within this kingdom, who shall be required upon any lawful occasion to take an oath in any case, where by law an oath is required, «* shall instead of an oath in the usual form be permitted to make his or her solemn " declaration or affirmation in those words following 5"

I. A. B* do felemnlyf sincerely, and truly, declare and affirm.

which said act, being only temporary, will expire at the end of this present session of Parliament: and whereas it is evident, that the said people called Quakers have not abused the liberty and indulgence allowed them by law, but on the contrary have given manifeE testimonyof their fidelity and good affection to his Majesty, and the settlement of the crown in the protestant line > and it is therefore reasonabteto give them the fame case and relief, as is provided for them by the said former act: be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by die authority of the same, That from and after the last day of this present session of Parliament every Quaker within this kingdom, who shall be required upon any lawful occasion to take an oath in any case, where by law an oath is required, shall instead of an oath in the usual form be permitted to make his or her solemn declaration or affirmation in these words following: viz.

IG. t.

recited.

I. A.B. do solemnlyt sincerely^ and truly declare and affirm.

which said solemn declaration or affirmation shall be adjudged and taken, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid that the fame be adjudged and taken, to be of the dime force and effect to all intents and purposes in all courts of justice and other places, where by law an oath is required, or shall hereafter be required, within this kingdom, as if such Quaker had taken an oath in (he usual form.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every person, who shall have made such solemn declaration or affirmation as aforesaid, and ihnl!

he lawfully convicted of wilfully, falsly, and corruptly, having declared or affirmed any matter or thing, which, if the fame had been sworn in the usual form, would have amounted to wilful and corrupt perjury, shall incur the fame peiuhics and forfeitures, as by the iaw anil statutes of this realm arc enacted against persons-i convicted of wilful and corrupt perjury.

IV. Provided also, That no person or persons Hull be deemed a Quaker or Quakers within the intention of this act, unless he, she, or they, shall affirm in the form aforesaid, that he, she, or they, is or are of the profession of the people called Quakers, and hath or have been so for one year then lait pall.

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed, adjudged, and taken to be, a publick act, and be judicially taken notice of as such by all judges, justices, and other persons whatsoever, without specially pleading Ihe fame.

VI. Provided, That this act shall continue in force for the space of eleven years, 19 c. a. it. and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, and no longer.

IX. And whereas the said highway or road leading from the said bridge to the town of Randalftown may be eonliderably shortened, and made much more convenient for travellers, if the fame was carried strait and in a direct line, where the lame is now crooked; for remedy whereof, and that all just and reasonable satisfaction may be given for the land made life of in carrying such road straight as aforesaid, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them,' to ascertain, describe, and set apart such a part and proportion of the lands adjoining or contiguous to the said highway or road, as they the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, shall judge necessary for carrying the fame straight and in a direct line; provided that no part of the said lands so to be set apart be built on, and that the fame be not part of any garden, orchard, yard, planted walk, or avenue to a houl’e, or of a park or paddock for deer; and the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, are hereby further authorized and impowered to treat and agree with the owners and others interested in the said ground, to be made use of in carrying the said road straight as aforesaid, for such recompence and satisfaction to be made for the fame out of the tolls and duties arising by virtue of this act, as the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, shall think fit or reasonable; and in case any person or persons shall neglect or refuse to treat or agree as aforesaid, or through any tlifability by nonage, coverture, or special limitation in any settlement or settlements, or by reason of any other impediment cannot, or otherwise howsoever shall refuse to, dispolc of their respective interests in such land, as the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, shall think convenient for the shortening of the said road, in every such case the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, are hereby authorized and impowered to issue forth their warrant or warrants to the flier ill’ or flierifls of the county, wherein such ground doth lie, to impannel and return before the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, tit such lime and place within the said county, as shall be appointed in such warrant or warrants, a sufficient jury, who upon their oaths (which said oaths the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, are hereby impowered and required to administer) shall inquire into the true and real value of such ground to lie made use of for the liiid highway or road; and such verdicts or inquisitions, as shall be so found and returned by the said jury ascertaining the value of such ground, shall be final and conclusive, as well to the said trul-tecs as to the several and respective owners and proprietors of such ground, notwithstanding any such disability or incapacity whatsoever.

CHAT*. XVIII.

An Act for repairing the Road leading from the Town of Armagh in the County Antrim.

WHEREAS the highway or road, leading from the town of Tiieroad Armagh in the county of Armagh to the town of Lilburn ^bylhc in the county of Antrim, by reason of the several hollow ways, and of the many and heavy carriages -frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in winter-season many parts thereof are impaiTable for waggons, carts, earn, and carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept m good and sufficient repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highway and road may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better surveying, ordering, and keeping in repair the said highway or road his Truflrc* for grace the lord primate of Ireland, the right honourable Alexander earl of Antrim, the right honourable the lord viscount war/y.&V-Maflarecn, the right honourable Francis lord Conway, the right reverend father in God Charles lord bishop of Kildare, the right reverend father in God Henry lord bishop of Dromore, the honourable John Skellington, the honourable Clotworthy Skefling-ton cfqrs. CHAP. XIX.

An Act for repairing the Road leading from the Town of Armagh in the County of Armagh to the Town of Newry in the County of Down.

WHEREAS the highway or road, leading from the town

of Armagh in the county of Armagh to the town of 'f.'+ C 3" Newry in the county of Down, by reason of the several hollow ways, and of the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in winter-season many parts thereof are iinpalTable for waggons, carts, cars, and carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be clfedlually amended and kept in good and sufficient repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highways and roads may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and 'l’l'yo.ni hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety; be it enacted by the King’s 1110ft excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better Purveying, ordering, amending, and keeping in repair, the said highway or road, his grace the lord primate of all Ireland, the right honourable lord viscount Charlemont, the right Tiuttceifur honourable Trevor lord viscount Hillsborough, the right honour-_j(, able Charles lord viscount Faue, the right honourable Benjamin may fit, tic. XX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said trustees, or any five or more of them, may and are hereby impowered from time to time, as they shall see convenient or think fit, to compound or agree by the year or otherwise with any person. or persons using to travel through the turnpike or turnpikes, to be erected by virtue of this act, with any milch cows, horse, mare, or gelding, afs, or mule, or with any coach, berlin, calafli, cliaife, chair, waggon, cart, carr, or other carriage, for any sum or sums of money, to be paid quarterly from time to time after such agreement shall be made.

XXI. Provided also, and it is hereby declared, That no person shall he charged with any of the tolls or duties aforesaid, who shall pass through any of the turnpikes to be erected by this act, who shall carry any quantity of stones, gravel, or other materials for repairing the said road, or any of the roads in the parishes, in which the fame do lie, or in any of the neighbouring parishes; nor shall any person or persons be chargeable with the said toll or duty for any carts, cam, or waggons loaden with corn in the straw only; nor for any ploughs, harrows, or other implements of husbandry in order to the using or repairing of the fame in the several parishes, in which the said highway or road hereby intended to be repaired do lie; nor shall any toll or duty be demanded or taken at any of the turnpikes to be erected for any horse, mare,' gelding, afs, mule, or other cattle, going to water, or for any post-horse carrying the mail or packet, or for such horse as is or shall be used only to ride on by the owner or driver of any waggon, cart, or carriages, provided such horse pass through the said turnpike or turnpikes with such waggon, cart, or carriage; nor shall any toll or duty be demanded or taken for the horses of soldiers passing, that are upon

XXII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the toll or duty hereby granted shall take place and have continuance from and after the first Monday in April in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty six for and during the term of forty one years.

XXIII. Provided nevertheless, That if at any time before the expiration of the said term of forty one years all parts of the said road shall be sufficiently amended and repaired, and so adjudged by the majority of the trustees, appointed or hereafter to be chosen by virtue of this act, by an adjudication made, and re-payment of such money as shall have been advanced or borrowed, with interest for the fame, and the colts and charges thereof, the said tolls.and duties shall cease and determine; any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

XXIV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the continuing of a sufficient number of able persons to be trustees for putting in execution all and every the powers in this act contained , for and during the continuance thereof it shall and may be lawful to and for the said trustees, or any five or more of them, upon the death of any of the said trustees, or their removal, or refusing to act in the said trust, from time to time and at all times hereafter during the term aforesaid to cleft, nominate, and appoint in the room of such trustee or trustees so deceased, removed, or refusing to act, another fit and able person, or so many more fit and able persons living in the said county of Armagh, to be joined with the said trustees in the execution of all and every the power and powers in them reposed by virtue of this act; and all and every person or persons to he chosen trustee or trustees to join in putting this act in execution, as they are herein before qualified to do, shall and are hereby impowered to act to all intents and purposes in as full, large, and ample manner as the said trustees are by this act impowered to do, and so toties quoties as often as occasion shall require.

An Act for the Relief of Insolvent Debtors.

WHEREAS many persons by Losses and other misfortunes are rendered incapable of paying their whole debts, and though they are willing to make the utmost satisfaction, they can, are nevertheless detained in prison by their creditors and rendered useless, and a burthen to this kingdom: and whereas such unhappy debtors have always been deemed proper objects of publick compassion, and by several acts of Parliament have been discharged: for the relief therefore of insolvent prisoners who shall faithfully discover upon oath, and deliver up, and alTign all their estates and effects whatsoercr for the benefit of their creditors; and to prevent as far as possible the many frauds and abuses which in a great measure have obstructed the good end of such former acts, be it enacted by the ICing’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritua) and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every sheriff or Jherifls, goaler, or keeper of any prison or prisons in any county, city, town, and liberty, within this kingdom respectively, shall and is or are hereby impowered and required to take and make a true, exact, and petfed lift alphabetically of the name or names of all and every person or persons, who upon die twenty ninth day of September in die year one thousand seven hundred and thirty four was or wereadually a prisoner or prisoners in close confinement in the custody of any such fiierilf or sheriffs, goaler or goalers, or keepers of any prison respectively, upon any process whatsoever, for or by reason of any debt, damages, costs, sum, or sums of money, and of the rime when such prisoner or prisoners were charged in custody, together with the name or names of the person or persons at whose suit such prisoner or prisoners is or are de* tained, and shall deliver the same to the justices at their first general or quarter, sessions of the peace, to be had after the first day of May in the year one thousand seven hundred and thirty six for such county, city, town, or liberty respectively, and fiiatl in open court take an oath to the effect following, viz.

I A.B. do upon tny corporal oath in the presence of Almighty Godfolemnly ftuenr, profess, and declare, that all and every person and persons, whose name or names are in fried and contained in the foregoing lift by me now delivered and subscribed, were to the best of my knowledge and belief upon the twenty ninth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty four really and truly prisoners in the prison or goal of at the suit or suits of the several

persons therein respectivtly mentioned, and so have continued without any fraud or deceit by me, or any other to my knowledge, unto this day; and that the said lift is a true, txafl, perfect, and just lift of all such persons, as were really and truly prisoners in the said prison or goal of on the said twenty-ninth

day of September in the said year one thousand seven hundred and thirty four, and have from that time to this day continued in custody undischarged.

So help me God.

And whereas several persons, who were confined in prison on the twenty ninth day of September in the year one thousand seven hundred thirty and four, may have been removed to some other prison by process of law: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if the goaler of the prison, wherein any such prisoner was confined on the said twenty ninth day of September in the year one thousand seven hundred thirty and four, shall make affidavit of such confinement, and the continuance of it until the removal to such other prison as aforesaid, and shall transmit such affidavit, to be attested on oath at the sessions where such prisoner may claim to be discharged; and if the goaler of the prison where to such prisoner may have been or shall be removed as aforesaid, shall make oath in open court at such sessions as aforesaid of the actual confinement of such prisoner in the said prison from the time of his or her being brought thither by process of law as aforesaid to the time of the sessions, when such prisoner claims to be discharged as aforesaid, it shall and may be lawful for the justices of the peace at such sessions as aforesaid upon such oaths as aforesaid, and upon such prisoner’s performing all other matters required by this act, to discharge such prisoner as effectually, as if he or she had been confined in one and the fame prison, such prisoner swearing to his or her confinement in two prisons as aforesaid; any thing in this act to the contrary notwithstanding.

XX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if action of escape, or any suit or action, be brought against any justice or justices of the peace, sheriff-, goaler, or keeper of any prison, for performing their office in pursuance of this act, they may plead the general issue, and give this act in evidence; and if the plaintiff be nonsuited, or discontinue his action, or verdict pass against him, or judgment be given against him upon demurrer, the defendant shall have treble costs; provided that the discharging of any person by virtue of this act shall not acquit any other person from such debt, sum or sums of money, or any part thereof, but that all others shall be answerable for the fame in such manner, as they were before the passing of this act.

XXI. And whereas John Hankinson, late of the city of Dublin merchant, by his humble petition and Application hath set forth, That lie had been a considerable dealer in the said city, and lived in credit, but on account of several misfortunes and accidents in trade he was forced about three years since to withdraw himself, and has ever since been obliged to conceal himself; and the truth thereof appearing by evidence and certificate, and evidence of upwards of three fourths of his creditors in value of his inability to pay them their respective debts, and their consent to have him included within the benefit and intention of this act, notwithstandhig he was not in close confinement and in goal: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said John Hankinson shall be and is hereby discharged of and from all debt or debts now due from him, he the said John Hankinson taking the oath prescribed by this act, saving only that part which relates to the imprisonment of the said John Hankinson, and performing upon his part all other the requilites by this act appointed, and subject to all forfeitures and penalties by this act inflicted or to be inflicted on those, who shall receive the benefit thereof; any tiling in this act contained to the contrary thereof in any wise notwithstanding.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all cases, wherein by this act an oath is required, the folenin affirmation of any person being a quaker shall and may be accepted and taken in the place thereof 5 and every person making such affirmation, who shall be convicted of wilful and false affirming, shall incur and fufter such and the fame pains, penalties, and forfeituics, ns are inflicted and imposed by this act, or by any other laws and statutes of this realm, upon persons convicted of wilful and corrupt perjury.

Provided also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act, or any thing therein contained, shall not extend to rclenfe or discharge Thomas Grace, now in the custody of the marshal of the Four-courts Dublin at the suit of the executors of Henry Luttercl, cfqj deceasedj but that he the said Thomas Grace shall be and continue in goal or safe custody, as if this act had never been made.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading From the town of Mullingar in the county of Westmeath through the town of Ballynelack in the said count)', and through the town of Edgeworthftown in the county of Longford, to the town of Longford in the said county of Longford, by reason of the several hollow-ways, and of the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in winter-season many parts thereof arc impassable for waggons, carts, cars, and cariages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in good and sufficient repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highway and road may with convenient fpced be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety; be it enacted by the Ring’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better Purveying, ordering, amending, and keeping in repair the said highway or road, the right honourable George earl of Granard, the right reverend Arthur lord bishop of Meath, the right reverend Joliah lord bishop of Kilmore and Ardagh, the honourable Humphrey Butler esquire, the honourable George lord : Forbes, the right honourable Richard Tighe esquire, the right honourable Sir Henry King baronet, the right honourable Sir Edward Crofton baronet, the right honourable lieutenant-general Owen Wynne, the right honourable Henry Bingham esquire, Sir Richard Lcvingc baronet, Sir Arthur Achcfon baronet, Sir Henry Tuitc baronet, Sir John Bingham baronet, Sir Arthur Newcomen baronet, colonel Owen Wynne, James Wynne esquire, Michael Cuff esquire, Joshua Cooper, Robert Rockford, St. George Ulher St. George, John I’rcdon, Anthony Malone, Henry Lyons, Anthony Sheppard senior, Anthony Sheppard junior, Henry Edgeworth, Richard Malone, Herbert Price, John Rochford, William Handcock esquires, captain John Wynne,

and for any horse or other cattle loaden with turf, not drawing, one halfpenny; for every other horse, mare, gelding, mule, or afs, laden or unladen, and not drawing, one penny; for every drove of oxen, cows, or neat cattle, the sum of ten pence per score, and so in proportion for any greater or lesser number; XL. And forasmuch as the money, so to be collected by such receipt of the said toil, will not at present be sufficient for the speedy repairing of the said highways or roads: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, shall and may and are hereby impowered from time to time by writing under their respective hands and seals to assign over the said toll or duty hereby granted, or any part thereof, the costs and charges whereof to be born and paid out of such toll or duty, for any term or time during the continuance of this act, as a security for any sum or sums of money by them to be borrowed for that purpose, to such person or persons or their trustees, who shall advance or lend the fame, for the re-payment thereof with lawful interest, or less, if the fame can be so had; which said money so borrowed shall be applied and disposed of, as the toll or duty is by this act to be applied and disposed of, and to no other purpose whatsoever.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said trustees, or any fifteen or more of them, may and are hereby impowered from time to time, as they shall see convenient or think fit, to compound or agree by the year or otherwise with any person or persons using to travel.through the turnpike or -turnpikes to be erected with any milch cows, horse, mare, or gelding, afs or mule, or with any coach, berlin, calafii, chaifc, chair, waggon, cart*

carr, or other carriage, for any sum or films of money, to be said quarterly from time to time after such agreement shall be made.

XXI. Provided also, and it is hereby declared, That no person shall be charged with any of the tolls or duties aforesaid, who shall pass through any of the turnpikes to be erected by this act, who shall carry any quantities of (tones; gravel, or other materials, for repairing the said road, or any of the roads in the parishes in which the fame do lye, or in any of - the neighbouring par riflics; nor shall any person or persons be chargeable with the said toll or duty, for any cans, cars, or waggons, loaded with corn in the draw only; nor for any ploughs, harrows, or other implements of husbandry, in order to the using or repairing of the fame in the several parishes in which the said highways hereby intended to be repaired do lye; nor shall any toll or duty be demanded or taken at any of the turnpikes -to be created for any horse, marei gelding, afs, or mule, or other cattle going to water, or for any post-horse

carrying the mail or packet, or for such horse as is or -shall be used only

to ride on by the owner or driver of any waggon, cart, or carriage, provided such horse pass through-the said turnpike or turnpikes with such waggon, cart, or carriage; nor shall any toll or duty be demanded or taken for the liorfcs of soldiers puffing, that are upon -their march, or for any waggons, carts,

cars, or other carriages attending them;, or for horses, waggons, carts, cars, or other carriages'travelling with vagrants sent by pafles, or with prisoners transmitted from one part of the kingdom to another.

full day of May one thousand seven hundred and thirty six for and during the

term of forty one years.

CHAP.

The ninth Year of George II.

CHAP. XXIII.

An Act for repairing the Road leading from the Green of Kilcullen, in the County of Kildare to the ‘Town of Atby in the same County, and from thence through the Town of Stradbally to the Town of Timoho in the Queen's County.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading from the Green of Kilcullen in the county of Kildare to the town of Athy in the same county, and from thence through the town of Stradbally to the town of Timoho in the Queen’s-county, by reason of the several hollow ways, and the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in the winter-season many parts thereof are impafTable for waggons, carts, cars, and other carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in good and sufficient repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highway and road may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better surveying, ordering, amending, and keeping in repair, the said highway or road, the right honourable Robert earl of Kildare, the right honourable Richard carl of Cavan, the right honourable Edward earl of Drogheda, the right honourable Jolliua lord viscount Allen, the right honourable Brabazon lord viscount Duncannon, the right reverend Charles lord Bishop of Kildare, the right honourable William lord Castle-Durrow, the right honourable Thomas Carter esquire matter of the rolls, the honourable Richard Allen esquire, Maurice Keating esquire, Sir Walter Dixon Burrows baronet, Mark Anthony Morgan, John Bourke Edward Stratford, Nicholas Ayl-ward, Robert Downes, Thomas Burgh of Bret, John Digby, Robert Burton, Ephraim Dawl'on, captain John Warburton* Thomas Keating, Thomas Bunbury, Robert Burrows esquires, Sir John St. Leger knight, John Dillon esquire, colonel Clement Nevell Robert Pearcy esquire, Maurice Keating junior esquire, the honourable John Allen esquire, William Ryves esquire, John Waller esquire, Robert Harman esquire, Theobald Bourke esquire, Richard Mcredyth esquire, Robert Mcredyth esquire, John I.ieuthelier esquire, Thomas Burgh of Naas esquire, William Vol. VI. 4 S Burgh

*735-

j An Act for rebuilding the Cathedral Church of St. Finbarry in the City of Cork, and far ereSing a Work-house in the City of Cork for employing and maintaining . the Poor, punishing of Vagabonds, and providing for and educating Foundling Children.

WHEREAS the cathedral church of St. Finbarry in the city of Cork was by length of time grown so ruinous and decayed, that it was not safe for the inhabitants of the said parish to attend divine service therein; whereby it became absolutely necessary to pull down the fame in order to have it rebuilt: and whereas the oeconomy of the dean and chapter belonging to the said cathedral by reason of the smallness of its fund, and the inhabitants of the said parish by reason of their poverty, are unable to support the whole charge of rebuilding the said cathedral church: and whereas the necelfity, the number, and continual increase of the poor and idle vagrants within the city of Cork, and the county and liberties of the said city,

(many of whom, are able to work and earn their bread)' is very great, and become exceeding burthensome for want of work-houses to set them at work, and a sufficient authority to compel them thereto, and to regulate them therein: and whereas the mayor, sheriffs, and commonalty of the city of Cork for the encouragement of so necessary and charitable a work are willing to appropriate a convenient piece of ground for a yvork-house in the said city: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritua? and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and immediately after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and thirty six there be and shall be a corporation to continue for ever Aperj*tu»i within the county of the city of Cork; which corporation shall 3S" consist of the several persons herein after mentioned: (that is to say) C0*1 the lord bishop of Cork for the time being, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriffs, common council-men, and common speaker of the said city, together with twenty six persons of the commonalty of the city (exclusive of the common council-men and common speaker) to be elected annually by the mayor, sheriffs, and commonalty of the said city, or the major, part of them, in their open court of Doyer hundred assembled on every last Monday in the month of April.

II. Provided always, That no person whatsoever shall be capa- Rtfuicnti ble of being elected one of the said twenty six of the commonalty

And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said governors, or any fifteen or more of them, shall on or before the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and forty one by and with the consent of the mayor, {heriffs, and commonalty of the said city'of Cork set out and inclose by itself such parcel of ground then in the actual possession of the mayor, {heriffs, and commonalty of the said city, as they the said governors, or any fifteen or more of them, shall judge most convenient, to erect a work-house on in the said city; which said parcel of ground from and immediately on its being so set out. and inclosed shall be vested in the said governors and their successors for ever for the use of the work-house thereon to he built, and the support and maintenance of the poor therein to be employed, as herein after is mentioned.

VII. VIII. And forasmuch as the money to be raised by the said duties or impositions will not of a long time amount to such stock or sum, as may be sufficient for erecting the said work-house and offices proper and necessary thereto; be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said governors in their general court of assembly, fifteen at least being present, shall and may be impowered after four years from the commencement of this act shall be expired, by indenture or indentures under the common seal of the said corporation to convey and assure the said duties or impositions, hereby to be granted, as a security for any sum or sums of money to any person or persons, who shall or will advance the fame, which they the said governors in their said general court of assembly, fifteen at least being present, shall think necessary to be borrowed for erecting such work-house and offices proper thereto as aforesaid.

If An Act for explaining, amending, and making more effectual an Act, intituled, \An Act for repairing the Road leading from the City of Kilkenny to the Town of Clonmell in the County of Tipperary.]

jG.j. c. 19. ttvjii R£ AS an act passed in the fifth year of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, An act for repairing the road leading from the city of Kilkenny lo the town of Clonmell in the county of Tipperary, which was to commence from the first day of May one thousand seven hundred thirty and two, and was to continue and be in force for and during the term of twenty one years: the toll in and whereas it is found by experience, that the tolls, as appointed by the said act, will not produce a fund sufficient for amending and repairing the said road: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of May in the year of our Lord God one thousand seven hudred and thirty six, the following tolls shall be taken at the the toll to gates erected or to be erected on the said roads: (viz.) for every coach, berlin, chariot, calafli, chaise, or chair drawn by fix horses, geldings, or mares, the sum of one shilling and six pence; for every coach, berlin, chariot, calafli, chaise, or chair, drawn by four horses, geldings, or marcs, the sum of one shilling; for every coach, berlin, chariot, calafli, chaise, or chair, drawn by two horses, geldings, or mares, the sum of eight pence; for every waggon, wain, cart, or carriage with four wheels, the sum of five shillings; for every wain, cart, or carriage with two wheels, drawn with two horses, mares, geldings, afics, or mules, the sum of four pence; for every wain, cart, or carriage with two wheels drawn with three or more horses, mares, geldings, a(Tes, or mules, the sum of three shillings and six pence; for every carriage commonly called a chair or chaise with one horse, mare, or gelding, the sum of four pence; for every carr or other carriage having one horse, mare, or gelding, the sum of one penny half-penny, except cars or other carriages loaden with turf only, and drawn by one horse, gelding, mare, afs, or mule, which are hereby exempted from any of the tolls charged by this act; for every horse, mare, gelding, mule, or afs, with any person riding thereon, the sum of one penny half-penny; for every horse, gelding, marc, afs, or mule, laden, or unladen, and not having any person riding

thereon,

CHAP. I.

An Act for granting and continuing to his Majesty an additional Duty on Beer, Ale, Strong Waters, Wine, Tobacco, and other Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned.

CHAP. IV.

An Act for lie further Encouragement- of the Hempen and Flaxen Manufactures.

WHEREAS the railing of flax-feed and flax in this kingdom will greatly

increase the linen manufacture: and whereas great quantities of k

dom, at the distance of ten leagues at least from the port where such feed shall be 173 7, so flipped; every such merchant, so shipping of any quantity of such feed, making Chap. 4, oath, and giving certificate and bond as aforesaid, shall have and receive clear and free of all duties payable upon the export of flax-feed the sum of one shilling per buflicl as a premium for every bushel of such feed, to be paid by such officer or officers, and in such manner as drawbacks are usually paid.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty ninth day of September aforesaid, it shall and may be lawful to and for all and every the justices of the peace for the several and respective counties, from whence flax-feed shall or may hereafter be exported, and they are hereby enjoyned and required at every their quarter-sessions, to give in charge in opens court to the grand-jury there assembled to make enquiry and preferment upon their oaths of the common market-price of flax-feed, as the same shall be commonly bought and sold in every such county; which enquiry and presentment the said grand jury are hereby impowered and required to make.
