CHAP. VI.

An Act that all Proceedings in Courts of Justice within this Kingdom shall be in the English Language.

[4 G. 2. 26. Eng. 6 G. 2. 14. Eng.]

WHEREAS many and great mischiefs do frequently happen to the subjects of this kingdom from the proceedings in courts of justice being in an unknown language; those who are summoned and impleaded having no knowledge or understanding of what is alledged for or against them in the pleadings of their lawyers and attorneys, who use a character not legible to any but persons practising the law: to remedy those great mischiefs, and to protect the lives and fortunes of the subjects of this kingdom more effectually than heretofore from the peril of being ensnared, and brought into danger, by forms and proceedings in courts of justice in an unknown language, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same,

[All proceedings in courts of justice, patents, charters, pardons, commissions, &c. shall be in English,]

That from and after the first day of January one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight all writs, process, and returns thereof, and proceedings thereon, and all pleadings, rules, orders, indictments, informations, inquisitions, presentments, verdicts, prohibitions, certificates, and all patents, charters, pardons, commissions, records, judgments, statutes, recognizances, bonds, rolls, entries, fines, and recoveries, and all proceedings relating thereunto, and all proceedings of courts-leet, courts-baron, and customary-courts, and all copies thereof, and all proceedings whatsoever in any courts of justice within this kingdom, and which concern the law and administration of justice, shall be in the English tongue and language, and not in Latin or French, or any other tongue or language whatsoever,

[and in legible character, not in court-hand,]

and shall be written or printed in a common legible hand and character, and not in any hand commonly called Court-hand, with the like way of writing or printing, and with such abbreviations, as are now commonly used in the English language,

[and with usual abbreviations in English, and figures.]

and with the like manner of expressing numbers by figures as have been heretofore or are now commonly used in the said courts respectively; any law, custom, or usage,

408 The eleventh Year of George II.

A.D. 1737. Chap. 6.

heretofore to the contrary thereof notwithstanding;

[Penalty 20l. to prosecutor.]

and all and every person and persons, who shall write or print any of the proceedings, or other the matters or things above mentioned, in any hand commonly called Court-hand, or in any language except the English language, shall for every such offence forfeit and pay the sum of twenty pounds to any person, who shall sue for the same by action of debt, bill, plaint, or information, in any of his Majesty's courts of record in the Four-courts Dublin; wherein no essoign, protection, or wager of law, or more than one imparlance shall be allowed.

[6 G. 2. 14. Eng.]

II. Provided nevertheless, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid,

[But names of writs, process or technical words, may be expressed as commonly used,]

That such penalty shall not be extended to the expressing the proper or known names of writs, or other process, or technical words, in the same language as hath been commonly used, so as the same be written or printed in a common legible hand and character,

[so as not in court-hand.]

and not in any hand commonly called Court-hand;

[Prosecutions to be in three months.]

and that all prosecutions for offences against this act shall be commenced within three calendar months, after the same shall be committed.

[Schedules of debts to the crown before 1 January 1738, may be issued as formerly, by remembrancers, &c. if the process annexed in English and legible hand.]

III. Provided also, That the several officers in the several offices of the King’s and the lord-treasurer’s remembrancer, otherwise called in this kingdom the offices of the first and second remembrancer, and the offices of the clerk of the pipe, and the clerk of the estreats in his Majesty's court of Exchequer, shall and may write and send out in process for his Majesty's service rolls or schedules of all such debts, as have been forfeited and became due- and owing to his said Majesty before the said first day of January one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, in the same manner they used to do: provided the writ or process, to be annexed to the said rolls or schedules, shall be in the English tongue, and in a common legible hand, and according to the direction of this act; any thing herein contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

[4 G. 2. 26. Eng.]

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid,

[mistranslation, errors in form, mistakes in clerkship, may at any time be amended, paying reasonable colss.]

That mistranslation, variation in form by reason of translation, mispelling or mistake in clerkship, or pleadings, or proceedings begun or to be begun before the said first day of January one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, being part in Latin and part in English, shall be no error, nor make void any proceedings by reason thereof: but that all manner of mistranslation, errors in form, mispelling, mistakes in clerkship, may at any time be amended, whether in paper or on record or otherwise, before or after judgment upon payment of reasonable costs only.

[Commissions and proceedings in admi-]

V. Provided always, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That nothing in this act contained shall extend to certifying

The eleventh Year of George II. 409

A.D. 1737 Chap. 6.

[ralty may be certified in Latin.]

beyond the seas any case or proceedings in the court of admiralty; but that in such cases the commissions and proceedings may be certified in Latin, as formerly they have been.

[Statutes of jeofails, except in criminal cases, shall extend to the proceedings in English,]

VI. And whereas several good and profitable laws have been enacted, to the intent that the parties in all manner of actions and demands might not be delayed and hindred from obtaining the effect of their suites, after issue tried and judgment given, by reason of any subtle, ignorant, or defective pleadings, nor for any defect in form, commonly called jeofails: be it enacted and declared by the authority aforesaid, That all and every statute and statutes for the reformation and amending the delays, arising from any jeofails whatsoever, shall and may extend to all and every form and forms, and to all proceedings in courts of justice, except in criminal cases, when the forms and proceedings are in English; and that all and every error and mistake whatsoever, which would or might be amended and remedied by any statutes of jeofails, if the proceedings had been in Latin, all such errors and mistakes of the same and like nature, when the forms are in English, shall be deemed, and are hereby declared, to be amended and remedied by the statutes now in force for the amendment of any jeofails;

[construed most beneficially to prevent delays.]

and this clause shall be taken and construed in all courts of justice in the most ample and beneficial manner for the case and benefit of the parties, and to prevent frivolous and vexatious delays.

[Not to extend to the court of receipt of Exchequer.]

VII. And be it further declared and enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend, or be construed, deemed, or taken to extend, to the court of the receipt of his Majesty's Exchequer, or to any proceedings therein, or to any members or branches thereof.

[Officers whereof shall business as formerly. altered 17 G. 2. 8.]

VIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said court of receipt, and the several members thereof, and their under-officers, deputies, and clerks, shall carry on the business to them severally and respectively belonging and appertaining according to the usual course and antient method and practice, and in like manner, as if this act had never been made; any thing herein to the contrary thereof in any wise notwithstanding.

A.D. 1737.

CHAP. VII.

An Act for the more effectual preventing the enlisting of His Majesty's Subjects to serve as Soldiers in foreign Service without His Majesty's Licence.

[9 G. 2. 30. Eng.]

WHEREAS divers of his Majesty's subjects have been of late seduced to enlist themselves, and others have been carried away by force out of this kingdom, and compelled to enlist, and enter themselves as soldiers under foreign princes, states, or potentates; which practices are highly prejudicial to his Majesty's dominions: and whereas the laws now in force are not sufficient to put a stop to such illegal practices: for the better and more effectual preventing the same, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same,

[Subjects inlisting in foreign service, or going beyond sea with that intent,]

That from and after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight if any subject of his Majesty, his heirs, or successors, shall within this kingdom enlist, or enter himself, or shall go out of the same beyond the seas and enlist, or with an intent or in order to enlist, or enter himself as a non-commissioned officer or private soldier in the service of any foreign prince, state, or potentate;

[or perons procuring subjects so to do,]

u frauds and abuses in felling of corn by measure, and that

XIII. And whereas an act passed in the first year of his present Majesty's reign, A.D. intituled, An act for regulating the price and ajftze of bread and the marhets; which act j y 7, hath in a great measure proved ineffectual; the table of assize annexed to the said Qiapt j aft being found by experience to be calculated on a greater weight than is contained

in the quarter, or two strike barrels of corn; for remedy whereof, and that a just 7 £ and true method for the aflizing of bread upon the quarter of wheat, containing forty stone, as herein before set forth, may for the future be duly observed and kept, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the said first day of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, the lord mayor within the city of Dublin and the liberties thereof, and the mayor, sovereign, provost, or other chief magistrate for the time being of any other city, town-corporate, or borough, and the seneschals within the mnnnors or liberties of St. Sepulchre’s, Thomas-court, and Donore, and St. Patrick’s-close, or two or more justices of the peace in such towns and places where there shall be no such mayor, sovereign, provost, or chief magistrate, shall severally and respectively, and from time to time as there shall be occasion, set, ascertain, and appoint within their several and respective jurisdictions, the assize and weight of all sorts of bread to be sold or exposed to sale by any baker or other person whatsoever within the limits of their respective jurisdictions, having respect to the price which the grain, meal, or flour, whereof such bread shall be made, shall then bear in the several publick markets in or about the city, town-corporate, borough, mannor, liberty, or place where such assize shall be set, and making reasonable allowance to the bakers for their charges, pains, and livelihood, which said assize shall be set in avsir du-poize and not in troy weight.

XIV. And that the said assize may the more easily be ascertained; be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the said first day of August one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight no person or persons whatsoever shall make for falc, or fell, or expose to falc, any fort or sorts of bread, other than the several sorts of bread herein after mentioned (that is to say) white, wheaten, and houshold, and such other fort and sorts of bread as shall be publickly licensed ami allowed by the lord mayor within the said city of Dublin, and liberties thereof, or by the said chief magistrates, justices of the peace, or seneschals within their several and respective jurisdictions; all which several sorts of bread shall be made in the several and respective degrees according to the goodness of the several forts of grain, whereof the fame ought to be made; and the assize and weight of the said white, wheaten, and houshold bread made of wheat, shall be set and ascertained according to the table annexed to the said act of Parliament passed in the first t C. 2. it. year of the reign of his present Majesty King George the second, and no

other.

XVI. Provided always, That if any loaf, which shall not be of the proper weight, shall be a crusty loaf; and it shall appear by the oath or oaths of one or more credible witness or witnesses before the lord mayor of the said city for the time being, the chief magistrate or magistrates, justice or justices of the peace, and the said seneschals witlnn their respective liberties, that such loaf was, at the time the fame was put into the oven, of equal weight with any other loaf of the fame kind of bread baked at the same time and in the fame oven, and which shall appear to have the due and proper weight, which such Joaf ought to have, there shall be no fine paid for the deficiency of the weight of such loaf, in case the same shall be good bread in every other respect; but the same shall and may be forfeited at the discretion of the lord mayor, or chief magistrate or magistrates, justices or justices of the peace, and said seneschals within their respective liberties.

XVII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all convictions, to be made as aforesaid for offences against this act, shall be certified to the next general quarter-sessions of the peace of the county or place, where such convictions were made, to be there kept upon record by the respective clerks of the peace to be seen without fee or reward.

CHAP. XII.

An Act for the better Preservation of the Game.

WHEREAS the several laws, already made for the better preservation of 1.1 x. 1.

the game, have by experience been found not fulEcient to prevent dellroy- n,

tig the fame by reason of the multitude of higlers, cleevers, and other chapmen, ».t. I:1t-who give great encouragement to idfeand loose persons to neglect their lawful cm- *4’

ployments, and to follow and dellroy the fame; for remedy whereof, and the more 10 3-

effectual preservation of the game in this kingdom, be it enacted by the King’s most ay o. i. a.’ excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every of the laws now in being for the better preservati-011 of the game, not hereby repealed or altered, shall continue, remain, and be in the fame-force, as beforetlic making of this act.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any higlcr,

III. IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons, not qualified by the laws of this realm so to do, shall keep or ufc any grey-hounds, setting-dogs, tunnels, or any other engine to kill or destroy the game, and shall be thereof convicted upon the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses by the justice or justices of the peace, where such offence is committed as aforesaid, the person or persons so convicted shall forfeit the sum of five pounds; one half to be paid to the informer, and the other half to the poor of the parish where the offence was committed j the same to be levied by distress and sale of the offenders goods by warrant under the hand and seal of such justice or justices, before whom such person or persons shall be convicted as aforesaid *, and for want of such distress the offender or offenders shall be pub. lickly whipped on some market day through some market-town within the county, where such offence shall be committed.

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for any of his Majesty's justices of the peace in their respective counties, cities, or towns croporate, to take away any such hare, pheasant, partridge, grouse, quail, or black-game, or any other game, from any such higler, chapman, cleever, or carrier, or any other person or persons not qualified to kill the fame, as shall be found in their custody and possession \ and likewise to take away such dogs, nets, or other engines, which shall be in the power or custody of any person or persons not qualified by the laws to keep the fame, to their, own proper use without being accountable to any person or persons for the same.

VII. And whereas vety great numbers of wild fowl of several kinds are setroyed by the pernicious practice of driving and taking them with hays, tunnels, and other nets in bogs and boggy grounds, lakes, and broad waters, where fowl resort in the moulting time, and that at a season of the year when the fowl are Tick and moulting their feathers, and the flesh unsavoury and unwholesome, to the prejudice of those that buy them, and to the great damage and decay of the breed of wild fowl: be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons whatsoever between the first day of July and the first day of October in every year shall by hays, tunnels, or other nets, drive or take any wild duck, teal, widgeon, or any other fowl commonly reputed water fowl, in any of the boggs or boggy grounds, lakes, broad waters, or other places of resort for wild fowl, in the said moulting-season, such person or persons, who shall so offend, and thereof shall be convicted before any one or more of his Majesty's justices of the peace for the county, where such offence shall be committed, by the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses, shall for every wild duck; teal, or other water-fowl, so taken as aforesaid, forfeit and pay the sum of ten shillings; one moiety thereof to be paid to the informer, and the other moiety to the poor of the parish where such offence (halt be committed; the same to be levied by distress and fate of the offenders goods by warrant under the hands and seals of the justice and justices of the peace, before whom the offender shall be convicted, rendring the overplus to the owner (if any be) above the penalty and charge of distress; and for want of distress the offender or offenders shall be publickly whipped on some market-day through some market-town within the county, where such offence shall be committed; and the justice or justices of the peace, before whom such person or persons so offending shall be convicted, shall order such hays, nets, or tunnels, that were used in driving or taking the said wild fowl as aforesaid to be seized, and immediately destroyed in the presence of such justice or justices.

VIII. Provided that where any offender shall be punished by force of this act, he shall not be prosecuted, nor incur the penalty of any other law or statute, for the fame offence.

CHAP. XIV.

An Act for the further Improvement and Encouragement of the Fishery of this Kingdom.

WHEREAS the wealth and prosperity of this kingdom do in a great measure depend on the improvement and encouragement of the lifliery: and whereas the laws now in being arc defective in making proper regulations for carrying on the fishery, to the great discouragement of persons from undertaking so beneficial a branch of trade: be it cna£led by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of May, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, no drift-net shall be (hot at the mouth or entrance of any cove or creek, or in a fain-draft, at such time as any fain is working or attempting to work therein; and that in case any person shall offend therein, he shall forfeit twenty shillings to the use of the poor of the pnrish, where the said offence ..ftiallbc committed , to be levied by distress and sale of the offenders goods by war-"rant under the hands and seals of two justices of the peace of the county, where the offence shall be committed, and before whom the offence shall be proved by eon-session or oath.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no fain or drift-net shall after the time aforesaid (hoot on for fish, and that no boat shall after the time aforesaid go out to look for fish, from fun-seton any Saturday night until after fumfet on any Sunday night immediately following under a like penalty of twenty shillings; to be recovered and applied ns the former.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person or persons shall after the time aforesaid, interrupt the (hooting of any fain, after it is laid out, from taking its full compass, under a penalty of ten pounds *, to be recovered by civil bill, in like manner as fmnll debts arc recoverable, before justices of assize by the owner or owners of such fain so interrupted against the hewer or mailer of the boat so interrupting.

IV. Provided, That if two or more sains shall be on a bawl, and have an opportunity of (hooting into tby* fame fain-drift, ami shall at the same time attempt

to

The eleventh Year of George II.

435

to flioot towards or against the other, in such case the owners of the said sains shall A.D. be in partnership for the whole night until fun rife next morning, and share alike 1737. what fish shall be taken during that time in either or all the sains so (hooting. Chap. 14.

V. And whereas great quantities of nfli are frequently stolen from persons, who with great expence and toil take the fame and whereas they are disabled from obtaining satisfaction through the difficulty of proving their property in the fifii so stolen: to remedy which evil, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the first day of May, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, any person having no fishing-craft of his own property, in whose custody any pilchards shall be found within one mile of an established fishery, and who shall not be able to prove by one or more witness or witnesses on oath, that he or she bought the fame, or otherwise came by them lawfully, shall forfeit a sum, not exceeding ten shillings, over and above the value of the said pilchards, to the poor of the parish where such person so forfeiting shall inhabit; to be levied by distress and sale of his or her goods by warrant under the hands and seals of two justices of the peace; and for want of sufficient distress to answer the value of the said forfeiture, or in failure of payment of the said sum so forfeited, he or flie shall be publickly whipped in the next market-town on the next market-day by warrant under the hands and seals of the said two justices.

VI. And whereas a whale-fishery has been lately discovered and undertaken on the coast of this kingdom, which if pursued will greatly increase the riches of this nation: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the first day of May, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, the sum of twenty shillings shall be paid for every hundred weight of whale-finn, and the sum of ten shillings for every tun of oyl extracted from whales taken on the coasts of this kingdom, to be paid by the collector of the next port to the party so taking said whales, oath being first made before said col!c£tor (which oath the said collector is hereby impowered to ndminister) that the said finn or oyl was the product of a whale or whales taken on the coasts of this kingdom, and that the said finn was saved, and the said oyl was extracted, within this kingdom, and that no premium was before paid for them, or either of them.

VII. And whereas the laws made for the preservation of salmon have hitherto l0<% T proved incffectual: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the first day of May, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, any person or persons, in whose custody any salmon taken out cf season, and commonly known by the name or names of red* salmon, red-pale, red fidmon-palc, flatts, or spent salmon, or salmon-fry, or eel-fry, shall be found, or who shall be found exposing to sale any such fish, and thereof shall be convicted by confession, or by the oath of one or more credible witness or wunesses before any justice of the peace within the city, town, county, or liberty where the same shall be found or exposed to fide (which oath the said justice of the peace is hereby impowered to administer) shall be deemed to have destroyed such salmon or fidmon-pale, salmon-fry, or cel-fry, contrary to the intent and meaning of this att, and shall be subject to such penalties, as by an act made in the second year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the first, intituled, sin act to prevent the 1left ruction if salmon fryt and better preserving the fahionfjbery in this kingdom^ are to be inflicted on any person or persons offending against the said act.

VIII. And whereas many of his Majesty's subjects of this kingdom are by divers pretences hindered from fishing in the harbours of this kingdom, to the great hurt and prejudice of the nation, as well as the particular persons so hindered: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That for the future no person or persons inhabiting this kingdom shall be interrupted or molested from fishing, or landing any fish taken in' any harbour in this kingdom, under any pretence whatsoever.

CHAP. XVI.

An Act for the Relief of Insolvent Debtors.

WHEREAS many persons by Losses and other misfortunes are rendered incapable of paying their whole debts, and though they are willing to make the utmost satisfaction, they can, are nevertheless detained in prison by their creditors: and whereas such unhappy debtors have always been deemed the proper objects of publick companion, and by several acts of Parliament have been discharged: for the relief therefore of insolvent prisoners who shall faithfully discover upon oath, and deliver up, and assign all their estates and effects whatsoever for the benefit of their creditors; and to prevent as far as pollible the many frauds and abuses which in a great measure have obstructed the good end of such former acts, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every flicriff or sheriffs, goaler, or keeper of any prison or prisons in any county, city, liberty, or town-corporate within this kingdom respectively, shall and is or are hereby impowered and required to take and make a true, exact, and perfect lilt alphabetically of the name or names of all and every person or persons, who upon the fourth day of October one thousand seven hundred and thirty seven was or were actually a prisoner or prisoners in the custody of any such sheriff or sheriffs, goaler or goalers, or keeper of any prison respectively, upon any process whatsoever, for or by reason of any debt, damages, colls, sum, or sums of money, and of the time when such pri-foneror prisoners were charged in cultoily, together with the name or names of the person or persons at whose suit such prisoner or prisoners is or are detained, and shall deliver the same to the justices at their first general or quarter-sessions of the peace, to be held after the first day of May one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight for such county, city, or liberty respectively, and shall in open court make oath to the effect following, vh. XLV. Provided also, That no person, who as guardian, trustee, executor, or administrator, is indebted to any person or persons, shall be intitled to the benefit of this act; unless where any creditor or creditors, to whom such person or persons is or are so indebted, shall apply, as in manner before directed to oblige such guardian^ trustee, executor, or administrator, to take the benefit of the same.

XLVI. Provided also, That no person shall take any benefit, or be discharged by virtue of this act, who hath formerly been discharged out of goal by any act or acts heretofore parted for the relief of insolvent debtors.

An Act for repairing the Highroad from the Town of Tomivarab in the County of Tipperary to the Town of Silver-Mines, as also to the Town of Nenagh, and from the said Towns of Ne-ttagh and Silver-Mines by Shally-Orchard through the Town of Tullo in the said County to the City of Limerick,

CHAP. XIX.

An Act for the further explaining and amending the several Jits of Parliament now in Forcefor erclting Lamps in the City of Dublin and Liberties thereof.

WHEREAS an act passed in the sixth year of his late Majesty's reign, ^ intituled, din act for erecting and continuing lights in the city of Dublin, and the several liberties adjoining: and also in the cities of Cork and Limerick, and liberties thereof; which said act was amended by an act made in the eighth year of his Ciid late Majesty's reign, intituled, An act for amending an act intituled, An act 8 G. 1.16. for erect'tng and continuing lights in the city of Dublini and the several liberties adjoining } and also in the cities of Cork and Limsrick} and liberties thereof; which said act was explained and amended by another act, made in the third year of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, An act for explaining and amending an act made in the ftsth year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the ftifty intituled, An act for crefting and continuing lights in the city of Dublin, and the several liberties adjoining; and also in the cities of Cork and Limerick y and liberties thereof; j G. j. 23.

which said acts are now near expiring; but several parts of the said acts, being found to be extremely useful, are.thought fit to be continued: be it therefore enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all ami every clause, article, and provisoe therein contained touching and in rofpcft of William Aldrich and

Hugh Cummin of the city of Dublin merchants, their executors, administrators, 1* or nfligns, except such parts thereof as are altered by this act, shall remain and be in full force and effect, as they now (land, to all intents and purposes for the space of twenty one years to commence from the twenty fifth day of March next, which will be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight, and to the end of the next session of Parliament, and no longer.

II. And whereas the said William Aldrich and Hugh Cummin have been great losers by crefting and continuing lights in the said city and liberties thereof in manner, as prescribed by the before recited acts: and whereas the present method of raising money for crefting and continuing lights in the city of Dublin by obliging every house-keeper in the great ft reels and lanes to pay an equal sum, without <7. *«jt

regard had to the value of the respective houses in such llrc.'ts and lanes, hath 1

bmn looked upon and complained of as unequal and burthciUumc to the poorer fort: be it therefore enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of March one thousand seven hundred and thirty eight the fame number of lamps, required by the said former acts to be creeled and enlightened, fiinll be continued to be crested and enlightened by the said William Aldrich and Hugh Cummin, their executors, administrators, or assigns, during the continuance of this act; and that in lieu and ftcad of the several Turns by the said former asti appointed and directed to be paid to them the said William Aldrich and Hugh Cummin, their executors, administrators, and assigns, the sum of fifteen ftiillings per annum for each lamp be raised and paid to the said William Aldrich and Hugh Cummin, their executors, administrators, and assigns, by the several inhabitants of the said city of Dublin and liberties thereof rateably and in proportion to the several and respective sums each parishoner of the several and respective parishes of the said city and liberties thereof pays by way of watch-money upon any applotnient already made or hereafter to be made.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the several duties and aids, and the said tax of four findings in the pound, hereby granted unto your Majesty, shall in the first place be applied and paid by the vice-treasurer, or vice-treasurers, his or their deputy or deputies, to the discharge of the interest of the said sum of three hundred thousand pounds, or so much thereof as shall remain unpaid on the said twenty fifth day of December in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and thirty nine; and that all the furptus of the said aids and duties hereby granted to your Majesty, over and above what shall be sufficient to discharge the said interest of the said sum of three hundred thousand pounds, or so much thereof as shall be unpaid on the said twenty fifth day of December, one thousand seven hundred and thirty nine, shall be applied towards the discharge of the said principal sum of three hundred thousand pounds, or so much thereof as shall be unpaid on the said twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and thirty nine, in manner herein after mentioned: (viz.) That when and as often as such surplus received by the vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers, his or their deputy or deputies, shall amount to the sum of five thousand pounds, that then the vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers, his or their deputy or deputies, shall cause the numbers of all the receipts or orders, which shall remain unsatisfied on die twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and thirty nine, and die sums therein contained, to be written on several tickets or pieces of parchment, and to be rolled and sewed up and put into a box or urn, and well mixed together, and an indifferent person shall publickly between the hours of ten and twelve in the* forenoon of a day, to be by the said vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers, his or their deputy or deputies, publickly advertised in die Dublin Gazette for that purpose at lead twenty days before, at the office of the vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers draw out of such box or urn as many of the said tickets or pieces of parchment^ as the sums therein contained shall amount to the said sum of five thousand pounds, and the person or persons, die number of whose order or receipt shall be so drawn, his, or their executors, administrators, or assigns, shall, within twenty days after the said tickets or pieces of parchment shall be drawn, be paid by the said vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers, his or their deputy or deputies, the principal sums to him or them respectively due, with interest for the fame at the rate of five pounds per cent, per annum, hill paid, and shall upon payment thereof deliver up his and their several and respective orders and receipts to the said vice-treasurer or vice-treasurers, his or their deputy or deputies, to be cancelled, which he or they are hereby required to cancel accordingly; and the interest payable by. virtue of such orders or receipts shall ccafe from the expiration of twenty days, to be accounted from the day of drawing the said tickets or pieces of parchment

X\l. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any part of the said principal sum of three hundred thousand pounds (halt be due and unpaid on the twenty fifth day of December, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty one, the same shall be well and truly satisfied and paid unto the several and respective persons, their executors, administrators, and assigns respectively, to whom the same shall be then due, together with such interest for the fame, as shall be then due, at the rate of five pounds per cent. per annum, without any deduction, defalcation, or abatement whatsoever.

CHAP. V.

An Act to continue and amend an Act made in the ninth Year of the Reign of his present Majesty, intituled, An Act for the better regulating of Juries.

Git '\KT WHEREAS an act made in this kingdom in the ninth year of the reign W of his present Majesty, intituled, An fir the better regulating of juries, i<) G. j. io. hat], by experience been found hfeful and beneficial, and is now expiring: be it crafted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the said act, and every clause therein, save as is herein after mentioned, shall be and is hereby continued to the twenty fifth day of March, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, and no longer.

III. Provided also, That no clause in the said act shall extend to enable any judge or judges of assize to order a Iefs number than thirty six, or a greater number than sixty, on any venire to be returned by any officer, who hath the return of juries.

IV. CHAP.

The thirteenth Year of George II.

CHAP. VII.

An Act for allowing farther Time tv Persons in Offices or Employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an Act, intituled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons, well a fie fled to Tirs Majesty's government 1 6*

and the church of Ireland as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected, or have been prevented by sickness or other accidental causes, to take and subscribe the oaths, and to make and subscribe the declaration, and to receive the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the directions of an act made in this Kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popeiy, and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties and forfeitures: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penalties and incapacities in the said act, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabihties, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission: but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectual, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration, in manner as aforesaid any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding: nevertheless so ns such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of poperyf on or before the first day of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred amt forty.

II. Provided, That this act, or any thing therein contained, shall not extend to restore or imitlc any person or persons to any office or employment already actually avoided by judgment of any of his Majesty's courts of record, or already filled up by any other person: but that such office or employment shall be and remain in the person or persons, who is or are now intitled by law to the fame, as if this act had never been made.

CHAP. X.

519 A.D. 1739.

An Act to explain and amend an Aftpajfed In the sixth Year of the Reign of his late Majesty King George the first, intituled, An 6C»i. w. Act for the better regulating the Parif3-Watches, and amending the Highways in this Kingdom, and for preventing the Misapplication of publick Money.

WHEREAS the giving a reward for the apprehending and convitting thieves and robbers will be a great means to prevent robberies for the future: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with tire advice and con« sent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That a sum of money not exceeding five pounds shall be given as a reward to every watchman, or to any other person or persons, who findl apprehend and lodge in goal any thief or robber concerned in any robbery, for which death by law ought to be inflicted, who shall be after convicted of the said felony 5 and that the said money shall be raised by presentment of the grand-jury at the assizes of the county, where such robbery or felony, for which death ought to be inflicted, shall be committed, as other county charges arc raised.

II. And whereas the laying out of roads in straight lines from market-town to market-town would be a great case to travellers, and of general advantage to the kingdom; notwithstanding which the owners or occupiers of land adjoining to or near the said roads, do often refuse liberty to cut such roads in a direct line, though full fntisfaction and recompence be tendered to such owners and occupiers respectively for any damage to be done thereby: to remedy which be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the first day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty it shall and may be lawful to and for the grand-jury of any county at the assizes at the request of any person or persons by presentment, in which such person or persons name or names shall be expressed, to point out and ascertain the lands and places, where any new road shall be carried in as direct a line as possible, and of statutable breadth, from any market-town in the said county to any other market-town in the same county, or as far as the said county extends, to any other market-town in the next adjacent county.

III. Provided always, That where any such new road shall be appointed, the fame or any part thereof shall not be carried through any ground being built upon, 'or through any garden, orchard, yard, planted walk, or avenue to any house what-Ibever.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority- aforesaid, That if any owner or 1735. occupier of any part of the lands, through which such new. road is to be carried, Chap. to shall think him, her, or themselves aggrieved by such presentment, it shall and may ke lawful for such owners or occupiers to enter one or more traverse or traverses to such presentment; which traverse or traverses shall be tried at the next affixes without good cause ffiewn to the contrary; and the jury to try the same shall assess fitting damages and recompences to the owner or owners, occupier or occupiers, of such lands, or any part thereof, for their respective interests therein, to be paid by such person or persons at whose request such presentment shall be made; on payment of which to the person or persons so travelling the said presentment, or on lodging the said sum so assessed with the treasurer of the county for the use of such owners or occupiers respectively, it shall and may be lawful to and for the person or persons, at whose instance such presentment was made, to enter upon the said work, and to periled the fame, without interruption of the said owners or occupiers, or of any other whatsoever.

V. And whereas highroads made by preferments through fenny boggs, low and marfliy grounds, are frequently overflowed and under water by means of the drains or trenches on either fide thereof not being kept clean and scoured: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every proprietor of such boggy, low, and marfliy, grounds or bottoms, through which such road hath been or shall be hereafter made by the publick money of any county (except turnpike-roads) shall every third year scour such trenches, so as the water may freely run and be carried o(F; and in default thereof, that any two justices of the peace of the county, where such roads lie, may fend such proprietor notice in writing under their hands to clear and scour such trenches as aforesaid in six calendar months after the date of such notice; which if the said proprietor shall omit, that in such case the said justices of the peace may by warrant under their hands order the overseers of the parish, wherein such road is, to have the said drains or trenches cfle filially scoured, and levy the value of the said work on the proprietor’s goods and chattels, to be applied to the discharge of the work, deducing such reasonable charge to the overseers, as the justices aforesaid shall think fit, not exceeding two shillings and six pence for each day such overseers shall necessarily be employed in attending and finishing the said work.

VI. And whereas several persons do lay great quantities of dung, muck-mooring, and other filth, on the publick highways, to the annoyance of passengers, and great damage and impairing the said highway: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for any person or persons

The thirteenth Year of George II.

after the twenty fifth day of April, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty, to take and cany away with carts, carrs, or other conveyance, all or any such dung, muck-mooring, or other filth, as they shall find laid in any highway, and the same to apply to their own use; and in case any suit or action shall be commenced against any person or persons whatsoever for and upon account of the taking away any such dung, muck-mooring, or other filth as aforesaid, the defendant shall plead the general issue, and give the fp'ecial matter in evidence; and if a verdict shall go for the defendant, or if the plaintiff shall be nonsuit, or discontinue his suit, die defendant shall have and receive his treble colb; any law, cultom, or usage to the contrary notwithstanding.

VII. And whereas by fulfering the hedges on either fide of highways or roads to grow too high and overhang the said roads, the said roads are greatly annoyed, and the laws already made in this kingdom for remcdy thereof are ineffectual: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all hedges of white-thorn, black-thorn, sally, hazel, furze, and holly, growing on cither fide of any highways or roads in this kingdom (which arc not turnpike roads) shall be cut or clipped at a height not exceeding five feet by the owner or occupier of the ground, which shall be enclosed with such hedges (except the cnclosures of gardens, orchards, nurfcrles, and hop-yards) and upon neglect thereof for the space of fourteen days after notice in writing given for that purpose under the hand of the overseer or overseers to be appointed by the parish or grand-jury (which notice such overseer or overseers are hereby required to give, where the fame is requisite it shall and may be lawful to and for such overseer or overseers to cut down such hedges (except as aforesaid) according to the height aforesaid 5 the charges whereof shall be reimbursed the said overseer or overseers by such owner or occupier, his or her executors or administrators, by warrant under the hand and seal of any justice of the peace for such county; and if any overseer or overseers shall neglect his or their duty herein, he and they shall forfeit the sum of ten shillings Jlerltug for every default or neglect; the said penalty to be recovered by civil bill by any person, who shall first fuc for the same.

VIII. Provided always, that no notice shall be given to cut or clip any hedges, but between the twenty ninth day of September and the twentieth day of February in each year.

CHAP. XI.

An Act for the further Improvement of the Hempen and Flaxen Manufa3ttres of this Kingdom.

WHEREAS it hath been found by experience, that the laws now m being R.^ui rp concerning the making and manufacturing of linen and hempen cloths in c* z,6‘ this kingdom have hitherto proved ineffectual to restrain and prevent the frauds and abuses, which are used and practised in the making the said cloths, which ill practices tend very much to the discrediting of the said manufactures both at home and in foreign markets: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this parliament assembed, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of November one thousand seven hundred and forty, no weaver shall weave, nor any person or persons fell, or expose to falc, any plain linen-cloth, being of or exceeding the set of fourteen hundred, commonly called fourteen hundred cloths, which shall not be when green, and before the same shall be bleached or whitened, thirty eight inches broad at the lead, upon pain of forfeiting the sum of forty nullings for every such piece of linen cloth so woven, fold, or exposed to saie j and that no weaver shall make use of any reeds in weaving any plain linen cloths of the set of fourteen hundred, commonly called fourteen hundred cloths, or upwards, that shall not be forty indies wide at lead, upon pain of forfeiting the sum of forty shillings for every piece of such linen cloth by him woven in any reeds not forty inches wide at lead; and that uo tapper shall lap or damp any plain linen-cloth of the set of fourteen hundred commonly called fourteen hundred cloths, or upwards, that shall not when whitened be thirty iix inches broad at lead.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the fird day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty, every weaver shall truly damp in legible characters with oyl and lamp-black on every piece of green plain linen-cloth of the set of fourteen hundred, commonly called fourteen hundred cloths, or upwards, by him, his journeyman or apprentice woven, the number of hundreds contained in the breadth of such cloth, together with the fird letter of his chridian name, and also his fir-name at full length, upon pain of forfeiting the sum of forty shillings for every piece of such liueit cloth by him or them woven, and omitted to be marked as aforesaid; and that every weaver shall weave all linen and hempen yarn to him delivered into cloth of such certain breadth as shall be agreed upon between the owner and owners of such yarn and such weaver? provided such breadth be not contrary to this or any former law, upon pain of forfeiting to the owner or owners of such yarn the full value or price agreed upon for weaving such yarn; and that every rced-maker, or other person making reeds for weaving linen cloth or hempen cloth, shall equally divide all the splits in each and every reed by him made, and shall likewise set upon every such reed by him made a mark with an iron-brand, containing the first letter of Jus christian name and also his fir-name at length in plain legible characters, upon pain of forfeiting the sum of twenty shillings for every offence in not equally dividing the splits, or marking his name as aforesaid; and that no weaver shall make use of any reeds in weaving linen cloth or hempen cloth, that shall not be equally divided into splits, and marked as aforesaid, upon pain of forfeiting the sum of twenty shillings for every reed that’ such weaver shall make use of, that shall not be equally divided, and marked as aforesaid.

Provided also, That if the said office of weigh-mailers for the city of Corke shall become vacant by the death or removal of the said John Colthurst, Edmund Knapp, and Edward Hoare, or otherwise, then and in every such case it shall and may be lawful to and for the mayor, aldermen, and common council of the said city of Corke, by writing under the common seal of the said corporation to nominate and appoint two other persons to the said office of weigh-mailer; who after such nomination and appointment shall hold the same to them, and the survivor of them, to be executed by theml'elves, or the survivor of them, or his or their sufficient deputy or deputies, during the good behaviour of the persons so appointed, with the fame fees, and under the like regulations, conditions, rules, penalties, and forfeitures as the weigh-mailers of Corke now arc or shall be subject and liable to by the said recited and this present act for the due execution of the office of weigh-mailer, and to the fame power of removal as is herein appointed for the said John Colthurst, the said Edmund Knapp, and Edward Hoare, and their deputies respectively.

VI. CHAP. XIII.

An Act for amending and refairing the Highway or Road leading from the Town of Belfast in the County of Antrim, through the Parish of Carmony to the Town of Antrim, and from the Town of Randajjlown to the Ferry of Tuam in the said County.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading from the town of Belfast in the county of Antrim, through the parish of Carmony to the town of Antrim, and from the town of Randalftown to the ferry of Toom in the said county, by reason of the several hollow ways, and of the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in winter-season many parts thereof are impassable for waggons, carts, cars, and carriages, and very dan- The road gerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appoint- p°‘r‘j die ed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended ordinary

' , ' coitrfe.

and kept in good and sufficient repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highways and roads may with convenient fpced be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety; be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better surveying, ordering, amending, end keeping in repair the said highways and roads, it shall be Tnrltcu in the power of the right honourable Alexander earl of Antrim, ’cp"/"1"* for the right honourable Arthur earl of Donegal, the right honourable Clotworthy lord viscount Maffereen, the right honourable as if harp*-Trevor lord viscount Hilsborough, the right honourable Francis mjf lord baron Conway, the right honourable William Conolly, the honourable John Chichester, the honourable John Skeffington, the onooool. honourable Arthur Skeffington, the honourable John Skeffington junior, John Upton, Arthur Upton, Robert Colvil, Charles O’Ncile Hugh Henry, Arthur Hill, Edward Brice, Henry O’Hara, Hercules Rowley, Robert Hawkins Magill, Hercules Langford Rowley, Clotworthy O’Ncile, and John Moore esquire, Sir Robert Adair baronet, Arthur Dawson, George Conyngham, William Stewart,

CHAP. XIV.

An Act for repairing the Road leading from Timoboe in /be Queen's-Counly through Ballynekill, Burrow, Beggars-Inn, and from thence through the City of Cajbelf to the Town of Tipperary in the County of Tipperary.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading from Timo- hoe in the Queen’s-county through Ballynekil, Durrow, not to be Beggars-Inn, and from thence through the city of Cafliell to the tiuTorilnu? town of Tipperary in the county of Tipperary, by reason of the C°UI*' several hollow ways, and of the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, is become so ruinous and bad, that in the winter season many parts thereof are impassable for waggons, carts, carrs, and carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in good and sufficient repair: therefore, to the intent that the said highways and road may with convenient fpced be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel the fame with safety: be it enacted by the King’s 1110ft excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better surveying, ordering, amending, and keeping in repair the said highway and road it shall be in the power of his grace the most reverend Theophilus lord arch- i-niUt,

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That out of the first money arising by the profits of the several turnpikes to be erected the said trustees, or any five or more of them, shall first pay and discharge the expence of procuring this act of Parliament, and of erecting such turnpike or turnpikes, and building such toll-house or toll-houses; and from and after such charges and expences shall be fully satisfied and paid, that then and from thenceforth the profits arising, and the toll to be collected at any turnpike or turnpikes to be erected or set up on the road, leading from Timoho in the Queen’s-County through Ballynekill, Durrow, Beggars-Inn, and from thence through the city of Caihell to the town of Tipperary in the county of Tipperary, shall he applied for and towards the repair of the said road only, and not elsewhere.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons whatsoever, owning, renting, or occupying any land near unto which any turnpike is to be erected in pursuance of this act, shall for gain, reward, or otherwise, permit any person or persons whatsoever to pass through any gate, passage, or way, with any coach, berlin, chariot, calaih, chaise, or chair, waggon, wain, cart, canyor other carriage, or riding or driving any horse, afs, mule, or any sort of cattle, to avoid the payment of the toll hereby appointed to be paid, and shall be thereof convicted upon oath by one or more witness or witnesses before the said trustees, or any five or more of them, or before any one or more justice or justices of the peace for the county wherein such offence or offences shall be committed, who are hereby impowered and required to administer such oath, such person or persons shall forfeit and pay to the trustees appointed to put this act in execution the sum of ten shillings; to be levied by distress and sale of the offenders goods by warrant under the hand and seal or under the hands and seals of the said trustees, or any five or more of them, or such justice or justices, rendring the overplus (if any be) the charges in taking and disposing of the said goods being first deducted.

<—r—' t, CHAP. XV.

An Act for amending and repairing the Road leading from the Town of Clonmell in the County of Tipperary through the Towns of Clogheen, Mitchelflown, and to Dotieraile in the County of Cork.

WHEREAS the highway or road leading from the town of Clonmell in the county of Tipperary through C'ig9& 20 G. the towns of Clogheen, Mitchelflown, and to Doneraile in the lift id count}' of Cork* by reason of the several hollow ways, and of the many and heavy carriages frequently passing through the fame, are become so ruinous and bad, that in the winter season many parts thereof are itnpaffable for waggons, carts, carrs, and other carriages, and very dangerous for travellers, and cannot by the ordinary'course appointed by the laws and statutes of this realm be effectually amended and kept in good repair: wherefore, and to the intent that the said highways or roads may with convenient speed be effectually amended, and hereafter kept in good and sufficient repair, so that all persons may travel through the fame with safety: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and Commons in this prcl'cnt Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the better surveying, ordering, amend-Trustcci ing, and keeping in repair the said highway or road it shall be f°2 ’cY'ifi m ttte power of the right honourable James earl of Barrimore, my f«e, Vr. the right honourable Arthur Mahon lord viscount Doneraile, the right honourable James lord baron Kingston, the right ho-a7nfitrl>ld nourah'e James lord Buttcvant, the right honourable Henry Boyle »rioooo/. esquire speakerof the house of commons, the right honourable

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That out of the first money arising from the profits of the several turnpikes to be erected, the said trustees, or any five or more of them, shall first pay and discharge the expence of procuring this act of Parliament, and of erecting such turnpike or turnpikes, or building such toll-house or toll-houses; and from and after such charges and expences shall be fully satisfied and paid, that then and from thenceforth the profits arising, and the toll to be collected at any turnpike or turnpikes, to be erected and set up on the road leading from the town of Clonmell in the county of Tipperary through the towns of Clogheen, Mitchclftown, and to Doneraile in the county of Cork, shall be applied for and towards the repair of the said road only.

III. Provided also, That a sum not exceeding twenty five pounds shall be expended or laid out in erecting or building any toll house on the said road.

IX. An Act for granting and continuing to his Majesty an additional Duty on Beer, Ale, Strong Waters, Witie, Tobacco, and other Goods and Merchandizes therein mentioned.

WE your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, the commons of Ireland in Parliament assembled, having a just sense of your royal care for the prosperity of all your subjects, and well knowing that the security of this your realm, and the continuance of the many blessings we enjoy under your mild and auspicious reign, depends on the support of your Majesty's government, do most humbly beseech your Majesty that it may be enacted, and be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the several and respective duties, and impositions on beer, ale, strong waters, wine, tobacco, and other goods and merchandizes, which in and by an act of Parliament made and passed in the first year of your Majesty's reign, intituled, An At! fir granting ta bit Majfij on ailditicr.al

CHAP. IV.

An Act for allowing further Time to Persons in Offices or Employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an Act, intituled, An Act to prevent the further growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons, well affected to his Majesty's government

and the church of Ireland as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected, or have been prevented by sickness or other accidental causes to take and subscribe the oaths, and to make and subscribe the declaration, and to receive the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties and forfeitures: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal anjl commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penal-

z /June 6. ties and incapacities in the said act, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall he questioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission: but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectual, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration, in manner as aforesaid 5 any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding: nevertheless so as such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the first day^of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord, one thousand seven hundred and forty two.

II. Provided that this act, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend to restore or intitle any person or persons to any oflice or employment already actually avoided by judgment of any of his Majesty's courts of record, or already filled up by any other person: but that such oflice or employment shall be and remain in the person or persons who is or are now intitled by law to the fame, as if this act had never been made.

An AHfir the further Improvement of the Hempen and Flaxen Manufactures, and to encourage the raising of Flax-Seed in this Kingdom.

WHEREAS the raising of flax-feed and flax in this kingdom will greatly , o.o.

increase the linen manufacture: and whereas great quantities of 'tf*'4-' flax-feed and flax are imported every year from Riga and other parts, whillt as good might be raised within this kingdom, if duly promoted and encouraged: be it enacted by the Ring’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That for the spaee of five years from the twenty fifth day of December, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty three, and from thence to the end of the next fclfion of Parliament, when good found and merchantable flax-feed of the growth of this kingdom is or shall be put on {hip-board at Dundalk, or any port of this kingdom southward thereof, by any merchant or other person or persons, who mall make oath before the collector, surveyor, or land-waiter of such port (who are hereby impowered and required to administer the same) that he to the bell of his lkill and knowledge believes the said feed to be found and good, and that no premium was ever received thereon, and that the fame is of the growth of this kingdom, the collector of the port, where the said fe:d shall be put on ship-board as aforesaid, shall -on oath made as aforesaid, give without fee or reward unto such person or persons as aforesaid a certificate, wherein shall be expressed the quantity of feed so shipped, and the day of the month and year when the fame was (flipped, and that oath has been made before him as aforesaid, that then every such person or persons upon landing the said feed in any port of this kingdom five leagues or more northward of the said port of Dundalk, and delivering the said certificate, and making oath before the collector, surveyor, or land-waiter of the port, that the said feed lb landed is the -fame feed mentioned in the said certificate, which oath the co!e£tor, surveyor, or land-waiter of the port, is hereby impowered and required to administer, and upon bond being given by every such merchant or other person in the fuin of twenty shillings for every barrel of such flax-feed, and so in proportion for every greater quantity, that the said feed is good, found, and merchantable flax-feed, of the growth of this kingdom, and shall not be relanded or sent into any part of this -kingdom more south than five leagues north of Dundalk, shall be entitled to and receive from the col!e£lorof the port, where the fame islanded, as a premium the sum of one shilling for every bushel so landed, clear and free of all duties payable upon the export of flax-feed, to'be paid by such officer or officers in such manner as drawbacks are usually paid.

II. III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of December one thousand seven hundred and forty three aforesaid it Hull and may be lawful to and for all and every the justices of the peace for the several and respective counties, from whence flax-feed shall or may hereafter be exported, and they are hereby enjoyned and required at every their quarter-sessions, to give in charge in open court to the grand-jury there assembled to make enquiry and presentment upon their oaths of the common market-price of flax-feed, as the same shall be commonly bought and sold in every such county; which enquiry and presentment the said grand jury aTe hereby impowered and required to make.

IV. V. VI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the time that a convenient piece or parcel of ground, lying and being in the shire or county-town of any county within the provinces of Leinster, Munster, and Connaught, shall be purchased, conveyed, or otherwise allured with the approbation of the grand-juries of the assises held for such county to any person or persons, his or their heirs, upon trust and to the intent that a publick ware-house or market-house should be erected and built thereon for the lodging in and expoflug to falc any flaxen or hempen-yarn, flax and hemp, and flax-feed and hemp-feed, that then it shall and may be lawful to and for the grand-jury of such county, where such piece or parcel of grouud shall be so purchased or otherwise allured for the use and to the intent aforesaid, at the general assizes to be held in and for such county to present any sum or sums of money not exceeding in the whole the sum of three hundred pounds j to be levied, raised, and paid, in the fame and in like manner as other publick money is raised and paid in such counties, and when such money is so raised and paid, the same shall be applied in the crccting and building such publick ware-house or market-house on such piece or parcel of ground for the several uses and purposes as aforesaid; and after such ware-house or market-house shall be built and eretted, it shall and may be then lawful to and for the grand juries of such counties at the assises to present a sum not exceeding the sum of fifteen pounds per annum t for the salary of an officer to attend the said ware-house or market-house.

VII. And whereas the assizes for some counties within the provinces of Leinster, Munster, and Connaught, are held within the precincts or limits of counties of cities, and counties of towns, in places appointed and particularly provided for that purpose, and excluded from being part of such counties of cities and counties of towns; by reason whereof it may happen, that no convenient ground can be purchased or otherwise obtained for erecting and building such ware-house or market-house in the places, where such assises are held, so as to be within the same county; and in such case disputes may arise, what town shall be deemed and taken to be the shire or county town: to prevent therefore such inconveniencies, and to obviate all such differences, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the respective grand-juries of such counties within the provinces of Leinster, Munster, and Connaught, where the assizes arc held within the precincts or limits of any county of a city or county of a town, if a convenient piece or parcel of ground can be had or obtained in such county of a city or county of a town by purchase or other assurance to the purposes aforesaid, may present such sum or sums of money as aforesaid, for building and creeling such publick ware-house or market-house in such city or town for the uses and purposes aforesaid, and for the salary of the officer attending the fame: and such ware-house or market-house, when built, shall be c(teemed and taken tube the publick ware-house and market-house of the county erc£ting the fame in as full a manner, as if such ware-house or market-house was built in the shire-town, and shall from time to time be repaired by such county by presentment of the grand-jury, notwithstanding such ware-house or market-house lies in a different county, any thing herein before contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

VIII. And whereas the cutting of sail-cloth through the middle of the piece to prevent the obtaining of the premium more than once for the fame sail-cloth hath been found hurtful to the hempen manufacture of this kingdom, for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of pecember, which will be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty three, no canvas or sail-cloth Ihaft be cut for the purpose aforesaid* and that no person shall be entitled to any premium for any canvas or sail-cloth, other than such sail-cloth as shall be produced to the proper officer of the custom-house, having twenty double threads, being part of the warp left in loops, and without knotting at the middle of that end of the webb which is (aft in weaving; which loops or double threads, the officers, before whom such fati-cloth is produced, are hereby required to cut away *, which find loops or double threads are to be made by warping them from one single bobbin, and by putting each double thread through the fame split of the reed, and by cutting the geers through which the double threads pass, when the web is woven: and no collector, or other officer of the customs, shall sign any debenture or certificate to obtain a premium for any canvas or sail-cloth, the loops of which have been so cut, or for which the premium has been once allowed.

IX. An Act for the more effectual Transportation of Felons and Vagabonds.

WHEREAS the several acts of Parliament, passed in this kingdom for transporting felons and vagabonds to his Majesty's plantations in America, have been eluded, and in a great measure rendered ineffectual, by the dilhonelty and misbehaviour of the matters of the ships employed by the persons who contract for transporting such felons and vagabonds according to the said several acts, by their fraudulently landing and putting on Ihore the said felons and vagabonds in some part of this kingdom, or some part of Europe: for remedy whereof, be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fifth day of March in the year of our Lord God one thousand seven hundred and forty four if any matter or matters of flap or ships, who shall undertake to transport any such felons or vagabonds, who shall be ordered to be transported to any of his Majesty's plantations in America, shall fraudulently land or put on Ihore in any part of this kingdom or any part of Europe any such felons or vagabonds, undertaken by him or them to be transported, all and every such person and persons, so landing or putting on Ihore any such felons or vagabonds, being thereof lawfully convicted upon indictment for the aforesaid oifence, shall fulfer death as in cases of felony without benefit of clergy.
