VII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all the forfeitures and penalties inflicted by this act, other than such as are otherwise by this present act appointed, shall and maybe filed for and recovered, levied, and applied in such manner and form, and by such ways and methods, as are prescribed and appointed in and by an act of Parliament made in the fourteenth year of the reign of King 1.8^ Chmlcs the second, intituled, An act for settling of the excise or new impofl upon his Majesty, his heirs and successorst according to the book of rates therein inserted, with like remedy of appeal to the party or parties that shall think him or themselves aggrieved or injured, as by the said act is provided.

VIII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all and every person and persons who shall from and after the twenty fifth day of March in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four give or offer any bribe, recompence, or reward whatsoever, to any officer or officers of his Majesty's customs or excise to connive at, consent to, or permit any goods or merchandizes to be run into this kingdom, or to connive at any false or short entry of such goods or merchandizes, shall for every such offence, being indicted and convicted thereof, forfeit to.his Majesty, his heirs and successors, the sum of one hundred pounds fieri. and likewise that all and every officer and officers of his Majesty's customs or excise, who shall at any time after the said twenty fifth day of March one thousand seven hundred and forty four, accept of or take any bribe, recompence, or reward whatsoever, to connive at, consent to, or permit any goods or merchandizes to be run into this kingdom, or to connive at, consent to, or permit any false or short entry of tl\p fame, or to do any other act whereby his Majesty may be defrauded of the duties or any part thereof due and payable for such goods or merchandizes, shall upon conviction as aforesaid for every such offence forfeit to his Majesty, his heirs and successors the sum of one hundred pounds Jlerlittg.

IX. And whereas great frauds have been committed in his Majesty's revenue by counterfeiting inland permits and coast-cockets: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons shall at any time from and after the said twenty fifth day of March one thousand seven hundred and forty four counterfeit or forge any inland permit, let-pass, or coast-cocket, for the carriage of goods, in cases where by law permits, let-pafles, or coast-cockcts are required, or shall counterfeit or resemble any impression, (lamp, or mark provided or appointed, or to be provided or appointed, by the commissioners of his Majesty's revenue for the time being, or by any three or more of them, to be put to or upon any such permit, let-pass, or coast-cocket, or shall make use of any such counterfeit or forged permit, or coast-cockct, with such counterfeit impression, stamp, or mark, knowing the same to be counterfeit, being thereof legally convicted by the verdict of a jury of twelve men, or upon his or their confession shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall be transported to some of his Majesty's plantations in America, there to continue for the space of seven years.

X. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person, who shall be adjudged to be transported pursuant to this act, shall at any time within the space of seven years after such trnnfportation be found at large in this kingdom without some lawful cause, or not being licensed thereto by his Majesty, his heirs or successors, under his or their privy seal, or by the chief governor or governors of this kingdom for the time being, such person shall fuller death as a felon without the benefit of the clergy* any law or statute to the contrary notwithstanding, and shall and may be tried in any county of this kingdom, where he shall be taken or apprehended.

XI. Provided also, and be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That so much of this act as is not mentioned to be for continuing any former act or acts, clause or clauses in any former act or acts, shall continue and be in force for two years from the twenty fifth day of March next, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, and no longer.

CHAP. IX.

An Act for allowing further Time to Persons ht Offices or Employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an A&y intituled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons, well affected to his Majesty's government *su,rbi

ami the church of Ireland as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected, or been prevented by sickness or other accidental causes, from taking and subscribing the oaths, and making and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord's Supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the fecoml year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery and by their inadvertency may have incurved great penalties: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by ami with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penalties and incapacities in the find act, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth cf popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify ihcmfcivcs according to the said act, iV.all be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid j and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questicncd or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission: but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectuni, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration, in manner as aforesaid j any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding.

II. Provided such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration, in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the first day of August, which shall be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four.

III. Provided also, That this act, or any thing herein contained, Hull not extend to restore or intitle any person or persons to any office or employment already actually avoided by judgment of any of his Majesty's courts of record, or already filled up by any other person: hut that such office or employment shall be and remain in the person or persons, who is or are now intitled by law to the fame, as if this act had never been made.

CHAP. XII.

An Act to oblige Ships coming from Places infcBcd more cffeBually to perform their Quarantine, and for the better preventing the Plague being brought from foreign Parts into Ireland, and to hinder the spreading of InfcBion.

WHEREAS it is necessary, that some provision be made by Parliament for obliging ships and persons coming from places infefted with the plague 1C. 1.13. to per[orm quarantine, in such manner as hath been or shall be ordered by his G.a. 34. Majesty, his heirs or successors, and for punishing offenders therein in a more cx-16 c. 2.6. peditious manner than can be done by the ordinary methods of law, and for pre-G. 2.8. venting the spreading of infection: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Ma-*ii C , h by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons

These-oenteenth Year of George JI. 681

commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, A.D. That when any country or place is or shall be iufe&ed with the plague, all ships j 74J, and vessels arriving, ami all persons, goods, and merchandizes whatsoever coming, Chap. 12, or imported in such ships or vessels in or into any port or place within the kingdom -w

XIV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any officer or other person appointed to fee quarentine duly performed, or any person placed or appointed as a watchman upon any house, lazaret, flop, or other place for performance of quarentine in pursuance of this act, shall knowingly and willingly permit or suffer any person, flop, goods, or merchandizes, to depart or be conveyed out of such house, lazaret, ship, or other place respectively appointed for performance of quarentine, unless in such cases, and by such lycence, as are or shall be directed or permitted by some order or orders, made or to be made and notified by proclamation as aforesaid; then and in every of the said cases every such officer and persons so offending shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and shall suffer death as in cases of felony without benefit of clergy.

XV. And whereas it is notorious, that notwithstanding the many good laws made to prevent the clandestine importation of customable and prohibited goods and merchandizes, a pernicious trade of that kind is ilill carried on for the most part in open boats or vessels of fmnll burthen, which privately and in the night put into creeks and secret places on the coast, thereby escaping the observation of the officers of the revenue, which practices may prove highly detrimental to the safety of this kingdom during a time of infection: for prevention thereof be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That when any part of Ireland, Great Britain, or the isles of Guernsey, Jersey, Alderney, Sark, and Man, or any part of France,

XVI. And to the end that all persons may know how to demean themselves in the premisses, be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That when and as often as the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom, shall make any order or orders concerning quarentine, and the prevention of in-section, and notify the fame by proclamation as aforesaid, such proclamation shall be publickly read upon the next Sunday after the receipt of the fame, and the first Sunday in every month afterwards, during the time such orders shall continue in force immediately after the prayers in all parish-churches and other places set apart for divine worship within such counties and places, as shall he specified for that purpose in such proclamation.

XVII. And whereas certain places in foreign parts having for some time pad been and Hill continuing to be visited with the plague, it may be judged necessary by the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom, for securing thereof from so dreadful a calamity to prohibit or restrain the commerce between his Majesty's subjects and those of any other country or place, which is or shall be infefted with the plague: and whereas it will be requisite to enforce such prohibition or restraint by levere penalties: be it therefore enacted by the authority afore-iaiil, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom, by one or more proclamation or proclamations, to be issued at any time or times before the first day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four under the great seal of

XIX. And be it further eiiaded by the authority aforesaid, That all and every person and persons, who shall export or cause to be exported any goods, wares, or merchandizes, contrary to the tenor or true meaning of any such proclamation and of this all, shall forfeit double the value thereof; to be ascertained and recovered as the value of any uncustomed or prohibited goods is by law to be ascertained and recovered.

XX. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if at any time or times after the ifiiiing and publiftiing such proclamation or proclamations respectively as aforesaid any person or persons shall visit, go to, or frequent any kingdom, country, or place, which is or shall be infected with the plague, contrary to the tenor or true meaning of such proclamation or proclamations and of this all; then and in every such case the person so offending shall forfeit the sum of five hundred pounds; one moiety thereof to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, and the other moiety to him or them who will sue for the same by allion of debt, bill, plaint, or information, in any of his Majesty's courts of record at Dublin, and that if at any time or times aforesaid any ship or vessel, person or persons, coming from any kingdom, country, or place, winch is or shall be infelled with the plague, shall enter into, or any goods shall be landed out of such ship or vessel in, any port or place within the kingdom of Ireland contrary to the tenor or true meaning of such proclamation or proclamations, and of this all; every person offending therein respectively, and being thereof lawfully convilled, shall be adjudged guilty of felony, and fuller death as a felon, without benefit of clergy; and such ship or vessel, goods or merchandizes, so allually entring into or being landed

XXI. XXII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any action or suit shall be commenced against any person or persons for any thing done in pursuance of this present act, the defendant or defendants in such action or suit may plead the general issue, and give this act and the special matter in evidence at any tryal to be had thereupon, and that the fame was done in pursuance and by the authority of the said act; and if it shall appear so to have been done, then the jury shall find for the defendant or defendants; and if the plaintiff shall be non-suited, or discontinue his action after the defendant or defendants shall have appeared; or if judgment shall have been given upon any verdict or demurrer against the plaintiff, the defendant or defendants shall and may recover treble costs, and have the like remedy for the fame, as the defendant or defendants hath or have in other cases by law.

XXIII. Provided always, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no attainder of felony by virtue of this act shall extend to work any corruption of blood or forfeiture of any goods, chattels, lands, tenements, or hereditaments.

XXIV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act, and the several clauses and provisoes therein contained (except so much thereof as enables the lord lieutenant, or chief governor or governors of this kingdom for the time being to prohibit or restrain commerce between his Majesty's subjects and those of any other country or place infefted with the plague, and the several powers, provisoes, penalties, matters, and things relating thereto) shall commence and take efieft from and after the first day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four, and that the same shall continue in force for the space of two years, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, and no longer.

An Act for Licensing Hawkers and Pedlars; and fir the Encouragement of English ProteJhvH Schools.

An act for the improvement of his Majesa's revenue upon the granting of licences for the felting of ale and for, as fully to all intents and purposes, as if the provisions VoL.Vl. 8 fj in

in the said act for that purpose were particularly mentioned, and expressed, 1745. and enacted again, in the body of this act.

Chap. 5. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every pedlar, haw-

her, petty chapman, and other trading person and persons so travelling as aforesaid, shall before the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty six, and so likewise in every year, deliver or cause to be delivered to the collector, appointed pursuant to the said act for the district, where lie or she shall reside or dwell, a note in writing under his or her hand, or under the hand of some person'by her or him authorized in that behalf, how and in what manner he or flic will travel and trade, whether on foot, or with one or more horse or horses, afs or afies, mule or mules, or other bcaft or beasts of burthen, for her or his so travelling and trading 5 for which he or flie shall thereupon pay or cause to be paid unto such collector one moiety of the yearly duty herein before directed to be payable for the fame, and give security by bond with one or more sufficient sureties, to be taken in his Majesty's name, for the true payment of the other moiety of the said duties at the end of six calendar months, unless the party shall chuse to pay down the other moiety of the said yearly duty; in which case he or she shall be allowed after the rate of two shillings in the pound for prompt payment of the fame; and thereupon a licence shall be granted unto him or her so to travel or trade by such collector.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any such hawker, pedlar, or petty chapman, from and after the said twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty six be found trading as aforesaid without or contrary to such licence, such person shall for each and every such offence forfeit the sum of five pounds; one moiety thereof to the informer, and the other moiety to the Incorporated Society in Dublin for promoting English protestant schools; and that every person so trading, who upon demand made by any justice of the peace, or chief magifttate of any town corporate, or borough, where lie or flie shall so trade, shall refuse to produce and shew unto such justice of peace or chief magistrate his or her licence for so trading, to be granted as aforesaid, that then the person so refusing shall forfeit three pounds, to be paid to such justice of the peace or chief magistrate for the use of the said Incorporated Society; and for non-payment thereof shall fufier as a common vagrant, and be committed to the house of correction.

IV. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may he lawful for the said collectors of the several districts in this kingdom respectively, and they are hereby respectively directed, appointed, and required, upon the terms aforesaid, and upon the receipt and security given as aforesaid, to grant a licence under their respective hands to every hawker, pedlar, chapman, or any other trading person for him or herself, or for him or herself with one or more horses, asses, mules, or other beasts, which he or they shall travel with, as the case shall require; for which licence there shall be taken by such collectors for their own use one (lulling, and no more, unless such lmvkcr, pedlar, or petty chapman, shall travel with horse, nfs, or mule, or other bcaft of burthen, and in that case there shall be paid for such licence only two shillings, and no more, over and above the duties aforesaid; ntul that the said collectors shall keep separate and distinct accounts of the duties hereby granted, and pay the money arising thereby into his Majesty's treasury, as other money received by them for the use of his Majesty.

V. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said collectors shall be accountable to his Majesty for the duties hereby granted and shall be subject to the like penalties and forfeitures for not rendering a true account thereof, and paying the fame in manner afore mentioned, as they are and (land liable unto for not rendering a true account of any other money re-r\ived by them for the use of his Majesty.

X. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the said first day of May no flax or hemp shall be steeped or watered in any river, stream, brook, or running water, or in any bog-hole, or.turf-pit; and that no flax or hemp shall be steeped or watered in any hole or pit with (landing water for two years successively, unless such hole or pit is dug near the fide of a running river or rivulet from whence such hole or pit may be frequently supplied with freflt water; and that all flax and hemp steeped or watered contrary to the true intent and meaning hereof shall be forfeited to such person or persons, as shall. seize the fame, and inform thereof in manner herein after mentioned.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person or persons in making twine, ropes, or cordage, shall mix or cover any old hemp or hempen yarn within new hemp, or shall mix or work up together any flaxen tow and hemp, or shall sell or expose to sale any ropes, twine, or cordage made up of old and new hemp, or of hemp and flaxen tow, upon pain of forfeiting the sum of ten shillings for every parcel of such twine, ropes, or cordage, that shall be so made up, to the informer.

V. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all thread, whether white or coloured, and all boss made of double flaxen yarn, shall be reeled on a reel of forty four inches or more in circumference, and shall be divided into (kains, each (kain containing twelve threads; and that all tapes, commonly called diaper and twilled tapes, shall be made up in pieces, each piece containing twelve yards or upwards in length; and that all fine plain tapes, whether white or red, shall be made up in pieces, each piece containing twenty four yards or more; and that all tapes commonly called chats, inclcs, and filiating, shall be made up in pieces, each piece containing in length thirty six yards, and that such chats shall contain thirteen threads in breadth, inckles shall contain twenty one threads in breadth, narrow filiating shall contain thirty three threads in breadth, and broad filletting shall contain forty nine threads in breadth, or more; and all braids, ferretting, and Ihoe-lace, made of flaxen yarn, or of such yarn mixed with silk or worded, shall contain in length eighteen yards or more in each piece; and all thread laces, commonly called points, shall contain sixteen threads or more in breadth; and all white bobbin made of Angle flaxen yarn shall contain twenty four yards in length in each piece; and all bobbin made of double flaxen yarn shall contain in length twelve yards in each piece; and if any person or persons drill sell or expose to sale any thread, tapes, chats, inckles, filletting, braids, ferretting, (hoc-lace, points, or bobbin whatsoever, that is not conformable to the lengths, breadths, anil rules aforesaid, or if the fame or any of them be found in the custody or possession of any weaver,

shop-keeper, petty chapman, or retailer, then and an such case the same shall be forfeited to such person or persons, as shall seize the fame, and inform thereof in manner herein after mentioned.

WHEREAS many of his Majesty's subjects have withdrawn and do daily withdraw themselves into the dominions of Spain and France, now in open war with his Majesty, in hopes of being preferred to commands in the armies and fleets of those crowns, and are thereby encouraged and enabled" to promote rebellions in Great Britain and Ireland: for remedy thereof be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That every person, being his Majesty's natural born subject of this kingdom, who at any time since the eighth day of October in the year one thousand seven hundred and forty five hath been, or during the present wars with the French King or the King of Spain, or after they or either of them shall be at an end, shall be, an officer, soldier, or mariner, in the service of either of the said Kings without licence for that purpose under the privy seal, shall from and after the twenty fifth day of March in the year one thousand seven hundred and forty six be and be deemed to all intents and purposes disabled to hold or take any manors, lands, tenements, or hereditaments, or any money, goods, chattles, debts, or securities for money, or any real or personal estate of what nature or kind soever, or any trust, charge, property, benefit, estate, or interest whatsoever in, to, upon, or out of the fame by defeent or purchase, or as tenant by the courtesy, by will, gift, as next of kin, or otherwise howsoever, either for themselves or their heirs, executors, or administrators; CHAP. VIII.

An Act for allowing further Time to Persons in Offices or Employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an Act, intituled.

An Act to prevent the further growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons, well affected to Vis Majesty's government and die church of Ireland as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected, or been prevented by sickness or other accidental causes from taking nnd subscribing the oaths, and making, and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord’s supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Queen Anne, intituled, An off it prevail tie further growth of popery, and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority a Awfc, of the fame, That all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penaL tics or incapacities in the said act, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act,

shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed, and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid $ and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by Tcafon of such neglect or omission, but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be as good and effectual as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration, in manner as aforesaid; any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding.

II. Provided such person or persons do and shall take and subscribe the said oaths, and receive the said sacrament, and make, repeat, and subscribe the said declaration in such manner and form, and in such place and places, as are directed and appointed by the said act to prevent the further growth of popery, on or before the twenty fifth day of March, which shall be in the year of our Lord, one thousand seven hundred and forty eight

III. Provided also that this act, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend to rcfiorc or intitle any person or persons to any office or employment already adually avoided by judgment of any of his Majesty's courts of record, or already filled up by any other person: but that such office or employment shall be and remain in the person or persons who is or are now intitled by law to the fame, as if this act had never been made.

CHAP XII.

An Act for the better regulating of Corporations.

WHEREAS divers persons have of late illegally intruded themfel-ves into, and have taken upon themselves to execute the offices of mayors, bailiffs, portrieves, and other offices within cities, towns corporate, boroughs, and places within this kingdom; and where such offices were annual offices, it has heen found very difficult, if not impracticable, by the laws now in being, to bring to a trial and determination the right of such perlbus to the said offices within the compass of the year; and where such offices were not annual offices, it has been found difficult to try and determine the right of such persons to such offices, before they have done divers acts in their laid offices prejudicial to the peace, order, and good government within such cities, towns corporate, boroughs, and places, wherein they have respectively acted: and whereas divers persons, who had a right to such offices, or to be burgesses or freemen of such cities, towns corporate, boroughs, or places, have either been illegally turned out of the lame, or have been refused to be admitted thereto, having in many of the said cases no other remedy to procure themselves to be respectively admitted or restored to their said offices or franchises of being burgesses or freemen, than by writs of mandamus, the proceedings on which are very dilatory and expenfivewhereby great mischiefs have already ensued, and more are likely to enfuc, if not timely prevented: and whereas in many cities, boroughs, and towns corporate within this kingdom, the election of the mayor, bailiff or bailiffs, or other chief officer or officers, is by charter or antient ulage confined to a particular day or time, without any provision how to act or proceed in case no election be then made; and it frequently happens, that by such charter or usage, particular acts are required to be done at certain times in order to and for the complicating of such cleftions, and by the contrivance or default of the person or persons, who ought to hold the court, or preside in the assembly where such cleftions are to be made or such acts to be done, or by accident, it has sometimes happened, and may frequently do so, if not timely prevented, that no courts or assemblies have been held, or cleftions Vox. XI. And provided also, That no mayor, bailiff or bailiffs, or other chief officer or officers of any city, walled town, or corporation within this kingdom, comprized or comprehended within the rules, orders, and directions of the lord lieutenant and council aforesaid, shall take upon him or them to serve in the said offices, or any of them, until he or they shall be rel'pec-tively approved of by the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors, and the privy council of this kingdom, by order under their hands pursuant to the rules, orders, and directions aforesaid.

XII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any mayor, bailiff or bailiffs, or other chief officer or officers of any city, borough, or town corporate, shall voluntarily absent himself or themselves from, or knowingly and designedly prevent or hinder the election of any other mayor, bailiff or bailiffs, or other chief officer in the fame city, borough, or town corporate, upon the day or within the time appointed by charter or ancient usage, or by the rules, orders, and directions of the lord lieutenant and council aforesaid for such election, the person or persons so offending, being thereof lawfully convicted, shall for every such offence suffer imprisonment for the space of six months without bail or mainprize, and shall be for ever disabled to take, hold, or exercise any office belonging to the fame city, borough, or corporation.

CHAP. XIV.

767

A.D. 1745.

An Act for explaining an ABpajfed in the tenth Year of his late Majesty King William the Third, intituled, An Act for the Preservation of the Game, and the more easy Conviction of such as shall defray the same.

WHEREAS it has been found by experience, that the rigorous execution of an act of Parliament made in the tenth year of his late Majesty King William the third of glorious memory, intituled, An act for the preferoation of the game, and the more easy conviction of such as shall destroy the fame, has been the means, whereby many of his Majesty's protestant subjects have been discouraged from providing themselves with and keeping arms in their hands, and others have had their arms taken from them under colour and pretence of executing the said act of Parliament; in consequence whereof great numbers of protestant have been rendered totally ignorant of and unacquainted with the use and exercise of arms, and the protestant interest of this kingdom is thereby become weaker and more defenceless for remedy whereof.be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That notwithstanding the said recited act, or any thing therein contained, all and every of his Majesty's protestant subjects may keep and use arms necessary for the defence of his Majesty, the established government of this kingdom, their persons and properties, only; and that nothing in the aforementioned act of Parliament shall extend, or be construed to extend, to impower any justice of the peace or other magistrate, or any other person whatsoever, to take from or deprive any protestant of such arms, as he, flie, or they, shall keep or use in manner aforesaid.

II. Provided always, That nothing herein contained shall extend, or be construed to extend, to enable any person whatsoever, not qualified by the said recited act, to kill or destroy any game mentioned in the said act.

Ait AB for reviving and continuing several temporary Statutes.

WHEREAS the several temporary laws and statutes herein after mentioned are found by experience to be of general use, and fit to be revived and continued: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That one act made in this kingdom in the tenth year of the reign of his late Majesty King George the first, intituled, An act for continuing and amending an aB, intituled, An act for the better regulating the par'ifh watches, and amending the highways in this kingdom; and for the preventing the misapplicalion of publick money; and also for efablifing a regular watch in the city of Dublin: and to prevent mischiefs which may happen by graving ships in the river Liffey; which for so much as relates to the city of Dublin and the liberties thereof, and the liberties thereto adjoyning, was continued by an act made in the eleventh year of the reign of his present Majesty, intituled, An act for reviving, continuing, and explaining, and amending several temporary fatales, and for other purposes therein mentioned, until the twenty ninth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four, and from thence to the end of the then session of Parliament, shall be and is hereby continued until the twenty ninth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty six, and to the end of the then next session of Parliament: and that one other act made in the tenth year, of his said late Majesty's reign, intituled, An act for regulating abuses committed in buying and selling of cattle and ft ep in the several markets in this kingdom, which by the aforesaid act made in the eleventh year of his present Majesty was continued until the said twenty ninth day of September in the said year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, shall be likewise continued and is hereby continued until the said twenty ninth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty six, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament.

II. And be it further eiiaded by the authority aforesaid, That one act passed in the said ninth year of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, An act to prevent the evil ari/ing by the retailers of beer, ale, brandy, rum, geneva, aqua vita, and other spirituous

liquors,

The nineteenth Year of George II.

liquors, giving credit to servants, day-labourers, and other persons, who usually work or ply for hire or wages; which by the aforesaid act made in the eleventh year of his present Majesty, intituled, An act for reviving, continuing, and explaining and amending several temporary ftalutes, and for other purposes therein mentioned, was continued until the twenty ninth day of September in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty four, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, and no longer, shall be and is hereby continued for fourteen years, and to the end of the then next session of Parliament.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That one act made in the fjiid ninth year of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, An act for preventing frauds and abttfes committed in the making and vending xtnfonnd adulterated\ and bad drugs and medicines, which was by the aforesaid act of the eleventh year of his present Majesty's reign continued until the twenty ninth day of September one thousand seven hundred and forty four, and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, shall be and is hereby continued for seven years, and to the end of the then next session of Parliament.

IV. And whereas notwithstanding the said act of Parliament and the powers therein given divers apothecaries do conceal from the persons by the said act appointed to visit and search their fliops and ware-houses, their unfound, adulterated, and bad drugs and medicines, whereby the fame cannot be found, and after the departure of the said vifltors introduce the fame into their fliops, which are afterwards fold out to the poor, to the great detriment of the health of his Majesty's subjects: for remedy whereof be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the vifltors, by the said act required to visit the {hops and warc-houses of the several apothecaries, shall and may examine upon oath (which oath they are hereby impowered to administer) the journeymen, servants, and apprentices of such apothecaries to the quantities and qualities of all and every the drugs and medicines in his or their respective fliops, ware-houses, power, or custody, or in the hands of any person or persons in trust for them; and such vifltors are hereby required annually to make a report to the president and fellows of the college of physicians of the state and condition of such fliops, warc-house6, and the drugs and medicines therein contained, as they shall find contrary to the true intent and meaning of the said act; and such report when made the said preli-dent and college of physicians, not being less in number than live exclusive of the said vifltors, shall in one month after such report so made cause the same to be printed and published.

V. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That one act passed in the eleventh year of his present Majesty's reign, intituled, An act for the better prefemation of the game, which was to be in force for the space of seven years and from thence to the end of the then next session of Parliament, and no longer, except such parts, or so much thereof, as are altered by an act patTcd this session of Parliament, intituled, An act for explaining an act passed in the tenth year of his late Majesty King JWliam the third, intituled, An act for the preservation of the game, and the more easy conviction of such as shall defray the fame, shall be and is hereby continued for seven years, and from thence to the end of then next session of Parliament.

III. And whereas the bakers of the city of Dublin and liberties thereof have not the allowance intended for them by the said receited act on houfliold bread, in regard the quarter of corn, when baked into houfliold bread, will not produce as many loaves of the weight mentioned in the table of assize referred to by the said act, as will make up the middle price of corn, and the allowance intended for the bakers by the said receited act: be it therefore further enacted by the authority, aforesaid, That the Lord Mayor of the city of Dublin, and the fcnefchals of Saint Sepulchre's, Thomas-Court, and Donore, within their respective liberties be and are hereby directed to give the bakers in the said city and liberties an allowance of nine shillings on each quarter of corn for houfliold bread by adding the same to the middle price of wheat, to be calculated as herein and by the said former act. is directed, and to be set according to the table therein mentioned: and to give an allowance of eight shillings only on the quarter for white and wheaten bread, to be baked in the said city and liberties, by adding the same to the middle price of -wheat, and to be set according to the table in the said act mentioned: and th.it the feycral magistrates in this kingdom have the like powers within their several respective jurisdictions.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no altcratiou shall be made in the assize of bread, but when the middle price of the quarter of wheat Hull rife or fail six pence by the quarter; and that the odd pence, if any, over and abQve such sum of six pence by the quarter on the middle price, shall be alternately allowed, one week to the publick and another week to the baker.,

V. And in order more effectually to ascertain the middle price of wheat, meal, or flower, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That three hundred and half weight of flower shall be deemed equal to and be entred in the place of one quarter of wheat, according to the sum for which said quantity of flower shall from time to time be fold.

And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the twenty fifth day of March aforesaid, no person being a baker, exercising or using the trade of a baker, shall at the same time use or follow the trade or occupation of a meal-man, or shall fell meal in the said city and liberties thereof, during the time of his exercising the trade of a baker, on pain of forfeiting the sum of five pounds JUrUng for every such offence, to be levied by distress and sale of the

VII. And whereas bakers, often enter into combinations not to hake, when the assize of bread happens not to be made.to their liking; by which the inhabitants'of the places where such assize is (truck, are often distressed, andithe publick peace of such places.put in great hazard: be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That as often as the chief magistrate of any place, or other person authorized by law-to strike the assize of bread, shall have sufficient reason to suspect, -that any person, being a baker, exercising. or using the trade of a baker, within the.limits of his jurisdiction, shall wilfully neglect to bake or use his trade through or on account of any combination, he shall have entered into with any person . or persons, such -chief magistrate, or other person authorized by law to strike the assize of bread, -may summon by writing the person so suspected before him, and proceed to enquire into the cause of such person neglecting to bake or to use his trade.; and if he shall find by the oath of one or mqrq credible witness-or. witnesses,.'that such: baker, or person exercising or using the trade of a baker, neglected to bake, or use. his trade through or on account of any such combination, he shall fine the said baker, or person exercising or using the trade of a baker, in the sum of ten pounds; to be !evied.in the same manner as the other penalties are to be recovered by. this or the former act for the use of the poor of the parish, where such offender shall live; and if any baker or other person shall think himself injured or aggrieved by any such judgment of any chief magistrate, or other person authorized by law to strike the assize of bread, he may appeal to the next going justices of assize, or if in the-city of Dublin, or liberties of Saint Sepulchres, Thomas Court, and-Donore, to the judges of his Majesty's court of Kings bench at the next term, who shall have power to hear and finally to determine-every such appeal and the judgmentthereon given shall be conclusive to all parties.

VIII. And be it further-enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the lord mayor within the said city of Dublin- and Iiber-. ties thereof, and the chief magistrates, justices of the peace, and seneschals, within the respective jurisdictions from time to time to settle and ascertain the rates and prices of oatmeal to be. fold therein; regard being had-to. the prices at which oats , shall be fold within their jurisdictions respectively; making a reasonable allowance-for manufacturing such oatmeal: and that when the said rates and prices of oatmeal are so settled and ascertained by the magistrates as aforesaid, it shall and may ‘be lawful for the said magistrates in their several jurisdictions to oblige the meal-men, manufacturers of.oats for sale, to bring all meal-so made by them,.or such-.part thereof as the said magistrate shall think proper, into the publick market on -tile market day, and to:sell the same in such small quantities as the said magistrate shall think fit; and that any person or persons refusing to obey the directions of' .- the said magistrate.herfin shall be punishedas an ingrosser. of corn.

And whereas the said highway or road leading from the said meetings of the said three roads to Munftereven, and from thence to Rathbrenan-hill near the said town of Maryborough, may be considerably shortened, and made much more convenient for travellers, if the fame was carried in a straight and direct line, where the fame is now crooked: and whereas it would be of great use and convenience to travellers, if a straight and direct road was made from the said hill of Rathbrenan to the turn of the road on the lands of Cappoly near the house of Elinor Brenan, and so in a straight line to Ballyrone in the Queen’s-county aforesaid: wherefore, and that all just and reasonable satisfaction may be given for the land made of use in carrying the said roads straight as aforesaid; be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said trustees, or any nine or more of them, to ascertain, describe, and set apart such part and proportion of the lands adjoyning or contiguous to the said highway or road, as they the said trustees, or any nine or more of them, shall judge necessary for carrying the said road from the said meetings of the said three roads to Munftereven, and from thence to Rathbrennan-hill aforesaid, and from thence in a straight and a direct line to the turn of the road on the lands of Cappoly near the house of Elinor Brenan, and so in a straight line to Ballyrone aforesaid; provided that no part of the said lands, so to be set apart, be built on, and that the fame be not part of any garden, orchard, yard, planted walk, or avenue to a house, or of a park or paddock for deer; and the said trustees, or any twelve or more of them, are hereby further authorized and impowered to treat and agree with the owners and others interested in the said ground, to be made use of in carrying the said road from the said meetings of the said three roads to Rathbrenan-hill aforesaid, and from thence to Ballyrone aforesaid, in a straight and direct line as aforesaid, for such recompence and satisfaction to be made for the fame out of the tolls and duties arising by virtue of this act, as the said trustees, or any twelve or more of them, shall think fit and reasonable; and in case any person or persons shall neglect or refuse to treat or agree as aforesaid, or through any disability by nonage, coverture, or special limitation in any settlement or settlements, or by reason of any other impediment cannot, or otherwise liowfo-ever shall refule to dispose of their respective interestsin such. lands, as the said trustees, or any twelve or more of them, shall think convenient for making the said road as albrclaid; V. XII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons shall at any time be sued or prosecuted for any thing by him or them done or executed in pursuance of this act, he or they shall or may plead the general issue, and give this act and the special matter in evidence for his defence j and if upon a tryal a verdict shall pass for the defendant or defendants, or judgment shall be given against the plaintiff or plaintiffs upon demurrer, or the plaintiff or plaintiffs be non-suit, discontinue, or forbear prosecuting their said actions, then such defendant or defendants shall have double costs to him or them awarded against such plaintiff or plaintiffs 5 for which costs he shall have such remedy as in other cases, where costs are by law given to defendants.

XIII. Provided also, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no writ or writs of certiorari shall supersede execution or other proceedings upon any order or orders made by the said court of afliftatus, or any five or more of them, in pursuance of this act, but that execution and other proceedings shall and may be had thereupon, any such writ or writs, or allowance thereof notwithstanding.

CHAP. HI.

An Act for Uccnfwg Hawkers and Pedlars; and for the Encouragement of Engli/ls Protcfant Schools.

19 <7. 1. 5. ‘T'T'T" WHEREAS the encouragement of English protestant schools will be of 11'3* W great benefit to this kingdom, and it is reasonable that some publick fund shall be appointed and set apart for that purpose: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by die authority of the same, That from and after the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty eight until the twenty fifth day of June, which will be in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and fifty there shall be an* fwered and paid to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, by every hawker, pedlar, petty chapman, or any other trading person or persons going from town to town or to other mens houses, and travelling either on foot or with horse, horses, or otherwise, within this kingdom (except as herein after mentioned) carrying to fell or cxpofitig to sale any goods, wares, or merchandizes, a duty of twenty shillings by the year; and that every person so travelling with a horse, afs, or mule, or other beast bearing or drawing burthen, shall pay the sum of twenty shillings by the year from the said twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty eight to the twenty fifth day of June one thousand seven hundred and fifty, for each horse, afs, or mule, or other beast bearing or drawing burthen, he or (lie shall so travel with, over and above the said first mentioned duty of twenty shillings by the year; which said rates ami duties shall be collected by such person and persons, and in such manner, and by such ways and means, as the duty payable for licences to keep alc*houses is raifod ami collected by virtue of an act made in this 11 G a j kingdom in the' eleventh year of the reign of his present Majesty, intituled, An act for continuing and amending several laws hereiejore made relating to his Ala-jejlys revenue, and the more, effectual preventing the running of goodst as fully to all intents and purposes, as if the provisions in the said act for that purpose were particularly mentioned, and expressed, and enacted again, in the body of this act.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That every pedlar, hawker, petty chapman, and other trading person and persons so travelling as aforesaid, shall before the twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty eight, and so Iikcwife in every year, deliver or cause to be delivered to the collcdor of excise for the district, where he or flic shall reside or dwell, a note in writing under his or her hand, or under the hand of some person by her or him authorized in that behalf, how and in what manner he or (lie intends to travel and trade, whether on foot, or with one or more horse or horses, afs or asses, mule or mules, or other bead or beasts of burthen, for her or his so travelling and trading; for which he or flic shall thereupon pay or cause to be paid unto such collector the yearly duty herein before directed to be payable for the fame 5 and thereupon a licence shall he granted unto him or her so to travel or trade by such collcdor.

III. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any such haw* ker, pedlar, or petty chapman, from and after the said twenty fourth day of June one thousand seven hundred and forty eight be found trading as aforesaid without or contrary to such licence, such person shall for each and every such o(fence forfeit the sum of five pounds; one moiety thereof to the informer, and the other moiety to the Incorporated Society in Dublin for promoting English protestant schools.

IV. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the said collcdors of the several districts in this kingdom

K respectively.

The twenty first Year of George II. 819

respectively, and they are hereby respectively directed, appointed, and required, upon the terms aforesaid, and upon the receipt as aforesaid, to grant a licence under their respective hands to every hawker, pedlar, petty chapman, or any other trading person for him or herself, or for him or herself with one or more hotfes, asses, mules, or other beasts, which he or they shall travel with, as the case shall require; for which licence there shall be taken by such collectors for their own use one shilling, and no more, except such hawker, pedlar, or petty chapman, shall travel with horse, afs, or mule, or other heart of burthen, and in that case there shall be paid for such licence only two shillings, and no more, over and above the duties aforesaid and that the said collectors shall keep separate and distinct accounts of the duties hereby granted, and pay the money arising thereby into his Majesty's treasury, as other money received by them for the use of his Majesty.

V. And be it further emitted by the authority aforesaid, That the said col-lettors shall be accountable to his Majesty for the duties hereby granted and shall be subject to the like penalties and forfeitures for not rendering a true account thereof, and paying the fame in manner afore mentioned, as they are and Hand liable unto for not rendering a true account of any money received by them for the use of his Majesty.

VI. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the monies arising from the said duties hereby granted shall from time to time be brought into the receipt of his Majesty's Exchequer, and shall from time to time without any fee or deduction whatsoever be paid by the vice-treasurer or receiver-general of this kingdom to the Incorporated Society in Dublin for promoting English protestant schools, or to their treasurer for the time being, for the use of the said Incorporated Society.

VII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons whatsoever shall forge or counterfeit any licence or licences for the purposes aforesaid, or travel with such forged or counterfeit licence or licences, such person shall forfeit the sum of fifty pounds \ one moiety thereof to the King, and the other to him that shall prosecute or sue for the same; to be recovered by attion of debt, bill, plaint, or information, in any of his Majesty's courts of record at the Four courts in Dublin, in which no cfloin, protettion, or wager of law, or more than one imparlance, shall be allowed; and shall be subject to such other pains and penalties, as may be inflitted on persons for forgery.

VIII. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons shall be sued, molested, or troubled, for putting in execution any of the powers contained in this att, or for doing any matter or thing pursuant thereunto, such person or persons shall and may plead the general issue not guilty, and give the special matter in evidence; and if the plaintiiF or plaintiffs shall be nonsuited, or judgment be given ngatnrt him or them upon demurrer, or a verdict pass for the defendant or defendants, such defendant or defendants shall have his, her, or their treble costs; to be recovered in such manner, as where by law costs arc given to defendants.

IX. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any constable shall refuse or neglect upon due notice, or on his own view, to be aiding and assisting in the execution of this act, being thereunto required, every such conftnble, being thereof convicted by the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses before any justice of the peace for the county or place, where such offence shall be committed, shall forfeit for each ami every such offence contrary to this att the sum of forty shillings; to be levied by dirtrefe and sale of the offenders goods by warrant under the hand and seal of such justice of the peace; one moiety to the Incorporated Society, the other moiety to the informer who shall prosecute for the fame, rendering the overplus thereof to the owner, if any be.

Provided always, and be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act or any thing herein contained shall not extend to prohibit any person from felling of any acts of Parliament, forms of prayer, proclamations, gazettes, almanacks, or other printed papers, or any fish, fruit, or victuals; nor to hinder any person or persons, who are the real workers or makers of any goods or wares within this kingdom, or his or their wife or wives, apprentice or apprentices, from carrying abroad, expoling to file, and felling, any of the said goods and wares of his, tier, or their making, in any publick fairs, markets, or elsewhere> nor any tinker, cooper, glazier, plumbers, harness-menders, or other persons usually trading In mending kettles, tubs, houshold-goods, or harness whatsoever, from going about, or carrying with him or them proper materials for mending the same.

XIII. Provided also, and be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act, or any thing herein contained, shall not extend or be construed to give any power for the licensfng* any hawker, pedlar, or petty chapman, to sell or expose to sale any wares or merchandizes in any city, borough, town corporate, or market-town within this realm, any otherwise than he or flie might have done before the making of this act: any thing herein contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

CHAP. V.

An Act for allowing further ‘Time to Persons in Offices or Employments to qualify themselves pursuant to an Act, intituled, An Act to prevent the further Growth of Popery.

WHEREAS several persons well affected to his Majesty's government and the church of Ireland, as by law established, may have through ignorance neglected, or been prevented by sickness or other unavoidable causes, from taking and subscribing the oaths, and making and subscribing the declaration, and from receiving the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, according to the directions of an act made in this kingdom in the second year of the reign of her late Majesty Anne 6. 'Queen Anne, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, and by their inadvertency may have incurred great penalties: be it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all and every person or persons, who have incurred any penalties and incapacities in the said act, intituled, An act to prevent the further growth of popery, mentioned, by neglecting to qualify themselves according to the said act, shall be and are hereby indemnified, freed and discharged of and from all incapacities, disabilities, forfeitures, and penalties, incurred by reason of such omission or neglect as aforesaid; and that no act or acts done by them, or any of them, or by authority derived from them, or any of them, and not yet avoided, shall be questioned or avoided by reason of such neglect or omission: but all such acts shall be, and are hereby declared and enacted to be, as good and effectual, as if all and every such person and persons had taken and subscribed the said oaths, and received the said sacrament, and made and subscribed the said declaration, in manner as aforesaid; any thing in the said act to the contrary notwithstanding.

CHAP. XII.

An Act for the more effectual Punishment of AJfaubs, with Intent to commit Robbery.

7 g. 2. n. tTTHER EA S many of his Majesty's subjects have been put W in great fear and danger of their lives, by wicked and evil-disposed persons assaulting and attempting to rob them: and -whereas the punishment of such offenders is not adequate to the heinousness of that crime, nor sufficient to deter wicked persons from such attempts: to the end therefore that all persons may be deterred from committing such offences, and for the greater punishment of such offenders, and for the more effectual preventing of the like mischiefs for the future; be- it enacted by the King’s most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the lords Spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same,

Assaulting That if any person or persons, from and after the first day of wcapon[orby June *n year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and r'cTmand forty Qght, w*th any offensive weapon or instrument un-ing money, lawfully and maliciously assault, or Shall by menaces, or in or by ttnt torob,"" any forcible or violent manner, demand any money, goods, or chattels of or from, any other person or persons, with a felonious intent to rob or commit robbery upon such person or per-

onconvic- fons, that then, and in every such case, all and every such person of felony1,y and persons so offending, being thereof lawfully convicted, Shall ported7ycar8 ^e an^ be adjudged guilty of felony, and every such offender and as other fc- offenders shall be subject and liable to be transported as in cases of felony; and the courts, by and before whom he, she, or they Shall be tried and convicted, Shall have full power and authority of transporting such offenders for the space of seven years, upon the like -terms and conditions, and by the fame ways and means, and in like manner as other felons may or are to be transported to any of his Majesty's colonies or plantations in America, by force or virtue of any law for that purpose now in being.

II. And whereas the repairing the said roads by their great length of way and the want of proper materials is looked upon as a project of great difficulty and expence for the said trustees to raise sufficient money for compleating the fame in any reasonable time: and whereas John Murphy, of Castle-Island in the county of Kerry gentleman hath proposed not only to be at the necessary expence of soliciting and defraying the fees of the several offices in this kingdom and Great Britain in obtaining this present act of Parliament, but also to lay out. and expend his own proper money in making and repairing the said roads, and to build and crcdt several bridges, turnpike gates, and toll-houses on said roads at the aforesaid rates; which proposal of the said John Murphy is contained in the words following: (that is to say)

XI. And for preventing frauds and abuses in the said tolls and duties, be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person or persons having paid the toll or duty by this act granted and made payable, and having such note or ticket, notes or tickets, as are hereby required, shall give or dispose of the same to any person or persons in order to avoid the payment of the said toll or duty, every such person giving, disposing, or offering, and the person receiving, such note or ticket, notes or tickets, and being thereof convicted upon the oath of one or more witness or witnesses before the said trustees, or any five or more of them, of before any one.or more justice or justices of the peace of the county wherein such offence or offences shall be committed, which oath the said trustees and the said justice or justices are hereby impowered to administer, shall respectively forfeit and pay the sum of ten shillings, to be levied, recovered, and disposed of, as any other penalty or forfeiture is directed to be levied, recovered, and disposed of by this act.

XII. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the tolls and duties hereby granted, shall take place and have continuance from and after the first day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and forty eight for and during the term of sixty one years,

XIII. Provided nevertheless, That if at any time before the expiration of the said term of sixty one years all parts of the said road shall be sufficiently amended and repaired, and so adjudged by the majority of trustees, appointed or hereafter to be chosen by virtue of this act, by an adjudication made, and repayment to the said John Murphy, his executors, administrators, and assigns, of such money as shall have been paid or borrowed, with the lawful interest for the fame, and the costs and charges thereof, the said tolls and duties shall cease and determine; any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

XVI. And be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this act shall be deemed, adjudged, and taken to be a publick act, and be judicially taken notice of as such by all judges, justices, and other persons whatsoever, without specially pleading the same.

The End of the SIXTH VOLUME.
